product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Misleading Color and Memory Availability...It's Black or Nothing!
review_body: UPDATE:  I forgot to mention that my first generation Kindle Fire HD has just been put out to pasture.   We had been trying to stream Netflix and Amazon Prime movies/TV shows to our HD TV - and getting frustrated in the process. The Netflix app often crashed, or told us we needed a high-speed connection to make it work (we have the fasted Internet connection possible for residents - 50Mbps). Plus, the shows frequently were so pixelated and clunky that we had to restart the Kindle frequently. Often, the episode just buffered endlessly.   We moved the cable modem and wireless to within 15 feet of the Kindle, thinking that may be helpful. It wasn't.   So we bought an Apple TV device - and were floored by the Blu-ray quality of the images. No buffering. No Netflax app crashes. The Apple TV device absolutely blew away the Kindle HD we were using.   My assessment is that the Kindle Fire HD (First Gen) wasn't built for speed, didn't have a fast enough processor, and had problems with wi-fi.   If you have been having rough, choppy streaming, slow connections, frequent app crashes, or buffering issues, it's likely because your Kindle Fire HD isn't up to the task. Buy an Apple TV device and enjoy super high-quality streaming without a hitch - in full surround sound.   I'll never go back to the Kindle Fire again - no matter what the generation. It's not good for streaming. We don't read books on it. And music doesn't sound all that great. In short, what's the point of having the Kindle Fire HD?   ___  I bought the first generation Kindle Fire HD with the 7in screen. For the most part, it's operated okay - if a little slow and fussy at times. (More about that in a minute.)  I was going to buy the latest generation of the Fire HD 7in. But the availability reminds me of the old joke about Henry Ford making cars back in the day: "You can have any color you want, as long as it's black."  That's the case here.  Amazon advertises a multitude of colors and options. Yet, when Itry to select a 16GB model in any color than black, I'm switched to an 8GB model or 6in screen model. Or, when I try to select the option of no advertising messages I'm shoved into the color black or 6in screen model. When it comes to those sponsored ads, what difference does it make what color or GB memory size I select?  I've been considering getting a new tablet, one with more memory or in other colors. I've kicked around an iPad, another Kindle, or a Samsung.  The fact that ordering the Kindle in any color other than black or size other than 8GB is near to impossible may tip the scale for me.  The Kindle Fire is okay. But I've owned iPads before and they're more powerful and now - thanks to the iPad Mini - just as light or lighter.  We use our Kindle Fire HD 7in for streaming Netflix or Amazon Prime movies/episodes. I've had problems keeping TV episodes on my Kindle Fire HD because Amazon keeps removing them. And I'm not talking about stuff I download from Prime. I'm talking about stuff I've paid for, that I allegedly "own." It sometimes turns up missing. I'd have to contact Amazon and explain what's going on. The rep would apologize and download it again for me. Later, it would disappear again.  Silk is an okay browser. But it's no Google. Plus, there are constant questions from the apps about how we want it to proceed.  The first gen Fire HD 7 was a great entry-level tablet for streaming stuff. But it's not all that good for reading (Paperwhite is superior for that purpose), and the battery runs out pretty quickly. We're constantly charging it - with a very short cord that makes using it while charging it difficult.  I may have taken up Amazon on their $99 price for a new HD 7. But, as I wrote, it's 8GB and black (with special offers) or nothing. There's so little memory available to users that the 8GB is not even close to what we'd need. Plus, I would have liked to have had more color choices than black.  I guess I'll try iPad or Samsung for my nexttablet.  That's not a slight against the Kindle. It's been fairly reliable for what we use it for. But I think we need to try something new - even if it does cost 2-3 times more. You get what you pay for.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Hard to see where this tablet is the best choice.
review_body: It is really hard to see where this tablet makes sense.  It is no cheaper than other androids.  I have compared it to my other 7" tablets and it sucks that battery quite a bit more, both when used and when resting.  I am constantly running into apps that won't work, app stores that cannot be accessed, and things that are glitchy.  Amazon has decided I CANNOT have my own wallpaper.  I CANNOT use Google Play.  In order to get Chrome, you have to really dig deep on the web, but Amazon has decided I CANNOT synch any bookmarks.  In general, it is a pretty limited tablet with some very useful features shut off.  Amazon support is sterling and some of the best I have found so that may tip the scale.  But if I had only one tablet, this would not be it.  Look carefully at what it will not do and be sure you don't want the missing features.  I am always reaching for the other tablet to do a lot of things that all the other tablets do with no problem.  I use the Fire about 30% of the time when it is for an app, but not for web access.  It is just to frustrating.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Will not connect to 5ghz band on Trendnet AC1900 Dual Band Wireless Router, TEW-818DRU
review_body: Will not connect to 5ghz band on Trendnet AC1900 Dual Band Wireless Router, TEW-818DRU with standard firmware.  This router has 802.11 a, b, g, n and ac functionality.  I read the specs for the Fire HD tablet before purchasing and it stated does support dual band, and since I already have FireTV that connects to this router no problem, I was surprised when the Fire HD tablet would not.  I googled around for solutions, seems other people are in the same boat with pretty much no success and were very disappointed.  I tried a lot of things and just gave up, and I'm really good with tech, being a linux geek.  It could connect at 2.4 ghz (the router has separate SSID's for each band, and each band has a unique SSID) but my whole reason for getting a new tablet was to replace my aging samsung table which does not have 5 ghz support.  So, I sent back the Fire HD tablet.  Was very disappointed.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: If you have spent much time using an iPad, ...
review_body:
If you have spent much time using an iPad, you will find this device frustrating. I'm a software product manager, and it I spent 15 minutes just trying to find the Settings screen. I finally found it by using the "Search" feature and searched for "Settings". A week later, I'm still not sure if you can find the device settings from the OS menu.

This device is very spammy. The home screen each time you start up the device features an advertisement. Within the first 3 seconds of using the Silk browser I received a "You have been selected for x..." popup. To receive said popup I simply typed youtube.com in browser and clicked "Go".

I summary, the Kindle Fire is a cheap iPad knock off. Half baked, and not very thought through. Then again, it's cheap

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: An Amazon tablet, not an Android tablet.
review_body:
Google is actively trying to strangle non-Google licensed Android devices from the market like this one. So before you buy this, consider:

1) No Google Play Store, where all of the best apps live
2) No Google Docs (Drive, Sheets, Docs, etc).
3) No Google Maps either
4) No Google Chrome
5) No Gmail app

You can read books, watch videos, etc. Think of it as a window into your Amazon content. Do NOT think of it as a general purpose Android tablet.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: I was happy when it arrived. It was well packaged, and arrived on time.  When I turned it on,  the image looked rather clean.  Then I set it up, nothing too tedious. Then I opened the interface.  The organization of the interface is annoying and haphazard. The options menu,  which you can always access, is well enough executed. However I noticed ads on everything, even my screen saver.  Thus far I've not found how to disable it, and set a background.  Furthermore,  although this is written with Android, you have no access to the Google play  store, and as such you are missing get out on many of the apps you may have on your other devices.  All in All its a nice monitor which streams Netflix well,  and you can read books on.  Besides that,  meh

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Quite possible the most durable tablet in existence.
review_body:
The kindle tablet is extremely durable. This allows my 3 year old to use it without fear of breaking. The tablet has taken multiple spills, dives and crashes and has never suffered a broken screen. I highly recommend a screen protector for this tablet if you have kids using it. I have had all sorts of mystery substances over this tablet but it still runs like a champ. Since the get go my kindle has suffered crashes, and freezes. I have tried unsuccessfully to download a app killer but that has done nothing. The tablet restarts whenever it feels like it, and the screen saver gets frozen.

*Pros
Extremely Durable one of the most rugged tablets I have ever used
Lots of amazon apps to download
Ez with the amazon apps
Free Music and Books threw the amazon store

Cons*
Frequent Crashes, Freezes and Malfunctions
If you already have prime the free year of prime is not included.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Comparing my 1st generation Kindle to my 4th gen. K.
review_body: Hate the instant on commercials!  Like my old 1st generation Fire better in a lot of ways.  New one doesn't hold charge as long.  Not sure if I like the front & back camera.  Feels like I'm being watched all the time.  They even said that they could 'observe' me & when they did a + sign would come on.  It comes on frequently. They said I could turn it off, but I've forgotten how to navigate there to find it.  The only reason I bought a new one is because the battery on the old wouldn't hold a charge at all if unplugged.  I need a longer cord for the new one so that I can use it in bed when the battery goes dead (this never happened on my brand new Fire 1 for a long time.)  Can't find where to purchase a longer cord on my new Kindle or on Amazon. They have it, because they showed it briefly & I thought I could go back later & order it, but couldn't find the site.  I like the fact that I can get to YouTube & watch any video I want at any time, as long as the battery is working. Couldn't do that on the older model.  Maybe it's still too new to me & I haven't gotten used to navigating it yet.  All in all, I would buy it again because the price is so low & the value so high compared to anything else.  It's light & small size will fit in an average purse which is wonderful for me.  The picture is excellent & the sound louder than my old one. I can hear it clearly now. LOL!

review_body:

I had a Kindle Fire a little over a year ago and I drop it aprroximately 3-feet from the floor and the screen went completely black and it would not work again. I called Amazon support and they would not replace it at all no matter who I spoke to. I decided to purchase a Samsung tablet from a local store and I have drop that a few times now, not on purpose of course, and it has never failed me.

DO NOT BELIEVE AMAZON'S TV COMMERCIALS ABOUT THIS PRODUCT, THEY ARE COMPLETELY UNTRUE!!!! Amazon needs to pull these ads immediately and stop their false advertising!!!!

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: A dud. A surprise fail from Amazon.
review_body: We are incredibly disappointed with this device, which partly reflects how psyched we were to get it, but also reflects its appallingly short battery life (like, left OFF on the bed during the day, goes from 100% to 50% -- unless we've got poltergeists, I can't imagine how that's happening) and difficulty to use. Considering returning it and getting another Nook HD instead, that's how bad it is. We can't easily change profiles, can't download music from our Prime library, can't read books I've bought *and* downloaded. It's just awful; maybe I got a defective one.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Love AMAZON- Hate this product... ADs and hard to navigate make it not worth it at all
review_body:
I have seldom been as disappointed in a product:
Two reasons NOT to buy:

1) This thing comes with ads. That's right ads. The first thing you see when you turn on your awesome beautiful machine is an Oreo commercial in HD. And I can pay $15 to make that go away. Nickel and dimed into hating a brand. I really can't believe it. Since they had a sale on their own product they now use that as an excuse to show ads. "Here Mom! Happy Mothers Day! Just swipe right past that commercial on to the front screen. Oh and you can't personalize the backgrounds. Or if you can, hell if I can figure out how without consulting multiple boards"

2) Even worse than ads... this is not easy to navigate. I got this for me mom and quickly realized that she would not be able to figure it out. I had to sit at the laptop and try to find help screens to figure out how to navigate this thing. And I didn't find much help. This is complicated by the ads and the content pushing which is overboard.

My 13-year-old nephew would view youtube all day on this and probably love this. For a senior, it's a terrible product since it's hard to navigate and for an 11-or-under-year-old it's terrible given all the clickbait. And I personally as a regular adult find it really annoying.

I have an Amazon FireTV stick and have been an Amazon prime member for years. And this product makes me sad.
I will be returning mine

review_body: It crap

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body:
The worst purchase I've made in decades. Where to begin? It's is a pretty little thing. The display is alright when it works. However, sometimes it takes several hours to boot up. I turn it on and just as often as not it doesn't work. One symptom is after it shows the Amazon logo the fire logo just sits there. Sometimes the animation works, sometimes it doesn't even do that. That can go on for hours. If I get past that stage the log in screen might show and it might not. When it does, before I can even swipe to unlock it, the confounded thing turns off and starts booting all over again.
Ok, let's say I am fortunate enough to get past the log in and am playing a game for example, pick one, any one. they all have frozen and stopped working. This just should not happen. I've tried to get rid of some of the apps. They magically reappear with their advertising and malfunctions. My particular Fire is probably the bad apple, but I can't stand the *&@?!! thing. It's aggravating and frustrating. That others are thrilled to the point of purchasing more than one is mind boggling to me. Buy this at your won risk!

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: The more I use this tablet the more restricted I feel and disappointed I become. I even bought this at a heavily discounted rate of $100 and don't feel like its worth that. For starters, it does not offer Instagram or Snapchat- two of the most popular social media apps for young millennials. Many popular apps aren't available on Amazon's platform- those two just seem like staples to me and you can't even get them! You also can't install background photos without installing an app that overrides the Fire's settings- I realize this is a minimal issue in the grand scheme of things, but come on! The ability to customize the background of an electronic device has been standard since 2004. It also frequently drops the WiFi signal when streaming any music or shows making it very frustrating- I don't think the antenna is very strong. I have always been an Apple person but wanted to see what Amazon had to offer for an e-reader/tablet but I've been sadly let down. I am most likely going to return an get the original kindle just for reading. Or maybe I'll pay up and get an iPad already....

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: I got this for $79 and for that price point, I feel it is a pretty good tablet. I have had this for only a day though. Will update periodically.  The good: 1. Nice hardware. 2. Easy to use interface. I already have a Kindle Fire 2012 and just had to connect to Wifi, download my apps from the Cloud and I was good to go in 10 min flat. 3. Sideloaded Dropbox, Viber and other google apps such as Google Drive. Fairly easy to set up. Not able to edit google documents though. Need to find a way around it :-) 4. ES Explorer is an absolute MUST. Connects to all cloud drives and effectively makes the low onboard storage an after thought. 5. Good enough display. I don't use the device much in the sun, so it works just fine for me. 6. Camera is an upgrade from my previous Kindle and I use it mainly for video conferencing. Serves the purpose very well. 7. Connected to a generic bluetooth keyboard easily.  The cons: 1. Opening screen makes it pretty hard to spot the arrow to swipe, but this is because of offers - a problem I knew about beforehand, but still a pain. 2. Need to figure out a way to disable that security feature! 3. Keyboard occasionally vanished and only way to make it reappear was a reboot. I installed a Swype keyboard application from the appstore and I have not seen this issue since. 4. The firmware update process was buggy - a lot of my icons vanished from the carousel and I had to re-start a few times to get it right. 5. Updated firmware is laggy even on the new hardware. 6. Battery life seems to be low. I have charged it 100% and it drains in about 6 hrs. My old Kindle Fire used to last 10 hours.  Update:5/8/15: 1. Figured out how to unlock the security screen. Simple enough :-) 2. Combining profiles worked really well for me and my wife.  Update: 5/18/15 1. Has been horribly laggy. Particularly loading the home screen when exiting an app and vice versa to the point I am considering returning it. 2. Battery life is worse than I had thought.

review_body:
Kind of disappointed. I need more apps. The ones available on the fire quite frankly don't even compare to Google play store for android. There is no way to organize photos and the apps available to do so aren't worth the trouble. So far I spent over $100 (product plus warranty) to play 2 games which isn't even why I bought it.

As a couponer, I need a way to organize photos into albums. I need apps such as walmart, lowes, kmart, etc. I need flipp and favado. This thing is worthless to me without it.

Not to mention Firefly NEVER finds an object I point it at. Ugh. What a waste of money.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Call customer service about increasing storage before you buy!
review_body:
Myself and others have voiced concern of not having enough gigabytes. 8Gb is not enough. After calling Amazon about this they stated that there is no way to add more. They recommended that I send data to cloud, which I did and it helped a little. Yet, the kindle would still come up with message that I ran out of storage. I have no pics, no email, a few apps, and no books, etc. At this time I continue to get the message of no storage. I also purchased a sundisk and I am not able to search or watch movies.
I'm going to try and connect to the computer to see if there are any programs running in the background. I loved my kindle but it looks like divorce may be inevitable.
Check out the reviews or problems from other users that experience the same thing.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: All my Personal Docs and Books Lost to Sight
review_body: Device just 'hid' all my (736) personal documents and > 400 books. After 3 years of satisfactory use, the Fire has just hidden all personal documents and books loaded on it.  They are shown in the Directory when it is attached to a laptop, but are not accessible on the device itself.  I had patient help from someone in the US and was then referred to a 'technical expert' overseas who started soliciting information by e-mail from the engineers while I was talking.  This is very poor customer service for a customer who chose Amazon over Apple. Won't make that mistake again.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: I just wanted a replacement for my original Kindle but this one is way too complicated and I still don't know how to access my books.  Someone who needs Internet, email and tablet or laptop-type capability will love it.  For me, a simple Kindle replacement would have been preferable.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: We bought 3 2nd generation 7" Kindle Fires for our boys in February of 2014.  They boys only use Kindle Freetime.  When we first got them, we were so happy with them that I talked everyone I could into buying a Kindle instead of an iPad for their kids.  Late last year, a software update was completed.  Since then, we have had nothing but problems.  We fight with storage issues almost every time the kids pick up their kindles.  I have spent countless hours on the phone with customer service and uninstalled and reinstalled software, done factory resets, and done every force stop they told me to...as well as repeating it on the other kindles when they start doing the same thing.  Even customer service is stumped at this point. If it were only one of the 3 kindles I would assume it was a glitch, but all 3 kindles are having the same issue.  The last factory reset gave us 1 week of usage (less than 5 hours of actual playtime).  The only games played at this point are the games provided by the Kindle FreeTime Unlimited subscription we have.  They are sending a replacement for the one kindle that is the worst at this point (the one most recently reset), so hopefully we will find a solution.  If we hadn't gotten so much enjoyment out of the Kindles when they were functioning correctly, I would have given fewer stars.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: Problem with sound volume.  For unknown reason/s, the volume does not remain constant as set.  It suddenly fades and no matter how high I adjust it, it remains so weak, it is difficult to hear.  The only recourse I have is to turn the unit off and after about a minute, turn it on again - but this is not the way it should be.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Riddled with ads, limited functionality, lacks important apps not found in the Amazon App Store
review_body:
Upon initially playing around with this device, I thought it was pretty great. It wasn't till I purchased one that I found a myriad of issues. I simply cannot recommend this device at all.

Pros:

- Affordable
- Nice physical design
- Durable

Cons:

- Riddled with ads that you have to pay 15.00 to get removed. They state that the ads are there to subsidize the low cost but why isn't this information given anywhere on the packaging? Had I known the device was subsidized with ads, I wouldn't have even considered it
- No custom software: I have the 4th gen edition of this device and the bootloader has not been exploited so no custom ROMS, no google play, or google apps for the matter
- The amazon software is garbage, looks nice but lacks functionality like custom backgrounds
- The app store is limited when compared to Google Play or App Store: many apps are simply not available on the platform. As of this writing, there is no way to get Google Play on this device
- The app store does not do refunds, all sales are final, unlike Google and Apple which have a time window to return app purchases. I purchased a manga reader app for my daughter and paid to remove the ads, amazon took 5 bucks and I still have ads with no recourse now

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: The Fire is a nice gadget but I'm disappointed in the extra weight and ...
review_body: I wanted to upgrade my old Kindle for my husband.  When I got the one day offer of $79 for the Kindle Fire,  I thought I would not only get an updated Kindle but a lot of extras.  The Fire is a nice gadget but I'm disappointed in the extra weight and size.  I'm comparing it to the old Kindle and my Nexus 7.  So far, I've not been able to discern any improvement of the Kindle reader itself other than flipping the pages with a finger.  Some of the apps I downloaded had to be opened with Facebook, so I deleted those...I hate Facebook.  I hope we enjoy the Fire as it is used more often.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Great device for the price, though it has storage issues.
review_body:
A nice device, especially for the price. It's quick, has good sound quality, and a nice display.

The minimal storage is problematic though. 16 GB doesn't really work well, particularly if your into reading comics and graphic novels.

Another issue with the memory that I find highly annoying is the fact that wi-fi is disabled when you reach anywhere near your maximum storage space. I'm actually a little surprised that a portion of the onboard storage wasn't dedicated to alleviate this issue. I run close to maxing out my storage in all my electronics and have never run into this problem before.

review_headline: buttons jamming after normal button presses.
review_body:
The power button doesn't put the machine to sleep or turn it off. The volume buttons also sometimes jam (without appearing to be jammed) and will move the volume slider all the way down. When using the touchscreen to move back the volume slider, the jam is still persistent on moving the slider until the tablet is muted. Sometimes when powering on it boots into safe mode. Not a fan of the tablet. An Ipad would never have problems with its buttons on adjusting volume and power.

On the plus side the device is pretty sturdy.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Thought it would be better, but I just traded one service for another.
review_body:
It looks nice, and has a nice display, but since it is a different operating system than both Apple and Android, there are many limitations to what can be installed on it. I bought it so that we could use all three of our favorite video services - Amazon Prime, Netflix and Vudu, but Vudo (Ultra Violet movies) are not supported on the Fire HD. I'm afraid if I had known that, it would have been a deal breaker. The other drawback is that unlike most android devices, there is no place to add more memory. My daughter has a cheap android tablet that was less than half what the Fire cost, but I was able to add a 32 gb mini SD so that I could put a lot of content on it. It really works well except for the fact that it couldn't get Amazon Prime movies, and it has an inferior camera. That's why I bought the Fire, but even though the Fire gives me Amazon Prime and a better camera, it doesn't give me other things that were important to me. So, if I want to have it all, I have to either have two different tablets, or I have to buy an ipad.The other thing that really bugs me is that every time you turn it on, it comes up with a new ad on the home screen. You can turn it off for an additional $15, but it is VERY annoying, and something that wasn't clear when I bought it.
Again, the display, camera, and ease of use is great. I also like the ability to set users for children that have restrictions and make it so they can't accidentally buy something, but I would only recommend it to everyone if it didn't have so many limitations and annoyances.

review_headline: Impluse buy! it was such a great price.....
review_body: Like always, I didn't know what it was I was buying. Old ladies, eh? This one will go back and I want the biggest, bad-ass HDX I can buy. If you are over 60 and you think this is going to do what your Chromebook does? That Facebook and Yahoo news will be configured the same? Not so. The screen on the Kindle is configured to Kindle and it's different. If you don't like change and expect this to be like your computer you will be disappointed. From what I understand, I can work my Smart TV with the HDX so, back this goes, on to a bigger memory', a nicer screen.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body:
Amazon has been a great company with good customer service until I called them regarding my son's kindle fire hd 7". It was dropped from the top of the bath tub to the floor (about 12") and the screen shattered, not just a crack. I saw Amazon's commercial the next day that shows the kindle being thrown down by a machine, then dropped from the top of a moving car where it bounces and it's picked up and it's perfect. Apparently, this is false advertising as these (mine) are NOT as durable as advertised. I know electronics should not be dropped, but accidents do happen occasionally.

Amazon customer service offered a whole $20 discount for a refurbished device. When the glass on mine obviously had some kind of defect causing the glass to shatter.

Buyer beware!! Very disappointed! I'm an Amazon Prime member and I will be rethinking how much I spend with Amazon from this point forward.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Fourth Kindle and they need to put HDMI jack back on their devices.
review_body: This is the fourth Kindle we've purchased and overall it's ben a pretty decent product for apps and books to read. I'd like to use it occassionally for streaming and every one has some new gizmo that Amazon sells you. I just ordered an HDMI adapter for this 4th generation Kindle Fire and we'll see what happens. Last Kindle we had to get a dongle device for miracasting. If Amazon hopes to sell me any more of their products then they need to put the micro HDMI jack back on their Kindles like the HDX we bought two devices ago. Good value for the money but I'd rather pay a tad more and have what I need. Okay I've used it for a week and also got the HDMI adaptor for this unit and it connects to tv fine and allows streaming from Kindle to tv. It's a little slower connecting to web pages on the internet verus our last two Kindles and you actually only get about 5GB of useable storage so people may want to consider the 16GB Kindle. Overall I bumped it up from a three to a four but wouldn't give it a five because of lacking HDMI micro jack and slow browser.  OKAY UPDATE! I've now used this Kindle for over four months and this is the worst one out there. I constantly have to turn the unit off because it locks up and it's too slow connecting compared to my spouses and the one I gave up to my grandson. I would only get a 16GB unit at minimum. Sorry but have to downgrade this device as unsatisfactory.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: I have mixed feelings about this tablet-- it's still new to me, so take that into account, however.  The screen images are pristine and the sound is far better than former tablets... that's the plus.  The negative is that it seems like they tried to create a wanna-be mac format, which I find uncomfortable in the first place.  Also I have yet to figure out how to get some of my favorite apps-- like nook (I realize that is the competition, however I have quite a library on it and don't want to give it up), and am having trouble even getting my playlist icon from my Amazon Prime music.  It's pretty far from "intuitive" and I suspect there's quite a learning curve. One thing I really don't like is that there is no option for an additional storage card--- everything goes to the "cloud", which I think  is ultimately a recipe for disaster.  It's like having a car with a lease-- you can buy the equipment, but you have to keep paying in order to use it.  Don't think I would buy this a second time.  I look forward to seeing what kind of help is available by way of real human beings!

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: Got the 7" 16gb version here, updating my original 5 star rating I gave it when I first got it only had using it for a week I had no idea the horror that I had purchased. I have had this since april of 2015, so 3 months later I have quite allot of time invested into using this machine and feel I have enough insight to give this review. First week, great, works amazing. Month goes by and I see that its getting sluggish, I do everything I know to remedy this 1. Ensure I am cold booting and not putting the machine to sleep so to refresh the ram and system everyday 2. Keep it well charged ensuring all the parts inside have enough power to work at their optimum levels 3. Get the best system cleaner app I can to ensure nothing runs that doesn't need to and everythings cleared out every once in awhile while using it. This did not help. I keep from downloading anything really mostly just using a couple books for school and the internet browser. Tried a couple game but uninstall when it feels sluggish.  2 months later things are even worse than ever. I do a factory reset after nothing works and the machine still runs like garbage. My cousins Nexus 7 2010 works better than this piece of trash. But I feel that after a couple more updates things might improve, maybe its a software issue. Well a couple updates later, 3 months later I am here to tell you this thing is a piece of trash. Is it worth buying? Sure, but not for what they are asking for. This is a $60-$80 machine at best. DO NOT BUY THIS!!! I am very disappointed in amazon and I regret this purchase everyday. Todays inspiring review update is from the system completely crashing on me while pausing a youtube video and stepping away for a moment. Upon returning the machine was completely unresponsive and I had to hold the power button to turn it off, then it wouldnt turn on and I got a message that the system crashed and recommended restoring factory setting -_- quad core, 1gb ram my ass. I don't know whats in this but its trash. My dual core, 1gb padfone x mini is twice as fast as this somehow and it is way more responsive too. Thats just embarrassing.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: I've owned practically one of each generation of Kindle Fire (7 inch) model.  I purchased this model after seeing a promo in 4/2015.  I wanted an upgrade in the software over the 2nd generation of devices.  The interface was snappy and I was able to load all of my apps from my previous kindle.  After about a week of moderate use, the device stopped responding.  I was able to contact support to troubleshoot the device, for which they are sending a replacement.  Unfortunately, they are out of stock and I have to wait almost a month to use my new device.  I'm just a bit disappointed in the build quality of this device as I have never had any issues with previous models.  The stinger is that I was told that I could use the apps or other devices to view my content.  I know that I can, but it makes me regret making this purchase and I will now think twice about future kindle purchases.

review_body: I like my fire. It's my 3rd one. BuT...oh yes...always a but...there is a learning curve. It disconnects from or has occasional trouble connecting to my WiFi. It hangs before connecting to sites. It gets confused sometimes and shuts itself down.  Let me be clear, it does this only intermittently. My iPad never has these types of problems BUT...there it is again....but, the Amazon community is the best for "fixes". Amazon customer service is flawless. There are lots of free apps and gimmees for the Fire and ... the most important part for me, I trust Amazon. I use both the Fire and ipad. I'm just more connected and informed with my Fire. So yeah, I gave it 3 stars but the Fire is the tablet I turn to most often. No tablet is 100% all the time. ??

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body:
I was disappointed.

The morning newspaper was delivered in the afternoon, if at all. It is still on April 26th edition and this is
April 30th. Yet, when I fire up my DX kindle the newspaper flows like always. I have tried to delete the whole mess and start over to no avail.

Also the carousel has issues. The Icons cannot be removed per instructions. I am afraid to push any harder and break the glass. The Choice to remove from device or carousel is not available.

Another joke on the consumer is the "swipe from top to bottom". Most of the time you can never find the home or backward icon.

If I were to do over, I would get the 16GB model. The 8GB model has less than 3 GB to work with after system requirements are met. I am a big fan of the Cloud and its versatility, but 3 GB is a real problem with a large library on hand.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Some good and not so good changes from the original Kindle Fire
review_body:
It's been a couple of weeks and I'm still not sure if I like this version of the Fire. My biggest complaint is that there's no rubber backing to keep it from slipping out of your hands, so I am always trying to hold onto it and not always succeeding. It has the shiny glass screen which picks up fingerprints like crazy instead of the matte screen that the Paperwhite has, which doesn't show fingerprints. When it's charging there's no light to tell you that it is or when it's done. Lots of unnecessary info when reading, such as how many minutes until the end of the chapter is annoying but I was able to easily turn it off. Not so easily turned off is the voice which constantly tells you what item # of how many item #s you are at. After repeatedly looking through the settings, reading info and watching videos I still had to call the help line to find out how to turn it off. (She said they get LOTS of these calls!)

I was hoping that the Collections feature would help to keep different genres of books separate, but when you put a book into a collection it still stays on the book page! I want them to disappear into a collection so that I can then look to see what's there. I have over 2,500 books and they all start looking alike after a while.

On the up side, the video and audio is much better than the old Kindle Fire. Some of my music has lyrics which makes it fun to sing along! Yahoo email and Facebook work very well, much better than the old Fire.

I would have happily kept my old Fire except that the port for charging is so loose that it takes forever to get it to start the charge.

We'll see how this works out...

There are a whole bunch of apps that would be REALLY nice to have, but they don't let you get them. Really there is a lot of improvement that needs to happen before I like this. Additionally, I paid for 8GB of space, and got 5. Actually, less then 5 because of the space taken up by the things already installed. Because I just spent an hour organizing all the books, I was exhausted and left the kindle to recharge while I did other things.  I came back after about 12 hours and I found the kindle complaining of a system boot failure and that my only option is to do a factory default wipe???  After I wasted all that time setting up the stupid books on the kindle, it dies?  This is a poorly designed piece of junk.  I am planning to return this.

I cannot get back to the home screen.  I am going to do a factory reset and then have to re-enter all the information.  Terrible, terrible instructions.  Seriously, I want to throw it across the room.  I thought this would be good for my father and for my son, but I'm going to return them both and buy iPads.  At least I can get customer service if I need to ask a question.  This machine just is not intuitive and is ridiculously difficult to make work.  The worst.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: No access to Google Play. Can?? fix nor root.
review_body: My wife bought me the Fire HD 7 as a birthday present. I tore open the box with great anticipation and now two weeks later I'm trying to figure out how to return it. This may seem odd because the device has no defect from Amazon's intended use. It may be great for you, but not for me! This device cannot access any app on Google Play whatsoever! It can only access apps on Amazon's App Store! And for you nerds, you cannot root this device. Read up on it. Therefore there's nothing you can do to fix it. If all you want is for your grandma to use Skype to talk to you it will be fine. But if you want to do anything useful on it other than that search Amazon to buy anything but a Kindle. I just don't get it.  I'm a huge repeat customer of Amazon.com.  Why do they even think they need to force me to ONLY use their app store?  If it weren't for that they'd sell a lot more of these devices. As I said.  Look it up. Research. I'm not alone in this opinion.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Kindle Fire no longer compatible with Zinio online magazine app
review_body: OK.  So I've had my Kindle Fire for a while now and have been moderately happy with it.  Having now used an iPad, I will say it is not nearly as user friendly (but I didn't expect it to be for the price).  I've read plenty of books, enjoyed my magazines. etc.  But suddenly Zinio (the digital publication company where my beading magazines reside) is no longer compatible with my Fire.  According to Zinio this is because their app wasn't accepted into the Amazon Store.  Oh, and the work around at Zinio help doesn't work.  Come on guys!  Why can't all of you corporate bigwigs get your acts together and just get along??  And guess what?  Zinio still works with Apple products.  The whole reason I went with the fire was because of it's price and because I would be able to take my magazines with me wherever I went.  Now that isn't possible except on my iPhone (which is too small to enjoy the beautiful photos and the instructions with diagrams) So I guess I'll just pony up the extra bucks for an iPad! Nice going Amazon and Zinio, I think you've both lost at least one customer over this one!

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: I purchased my Fire HD7  from QVC....loved the presentation, they made it sound so easy to set up.They even e-mailed me a video  explaining the two simple steps to get started......I was so excited to get my new Fire when it arrived , I watched the 45sec. video again only to find my device wouldn't work. So I eventually called tech service # and after almost 2 hrs. on the phone I was finally able to use my new purchase. After so much stress setting the thing up my excitement had turned sour towards the damn thing.......The apps that were suppose to be already set up; were not.  I'm still considering sending this back due to false advertising.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Difficult for programming apps with Google App Inventor
review_body: I got them so my students could create apps using Google App Inventor, but I was not aware that Amazon and Google could not play nice together. The hoops I am trying to jump through so these tablets are not a waste of money is time consuming and tedious. And I'm not so sure it will work in the end. I would not purchase these again for my classroom use.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: Amazon's Fire OS is complete and utter junk. The user interface is unusable at best.  As far as tablets go, who cares what the camera specs are (unless you are making a Skype call - seriously, no one uses a tablet to take pictures, do they?)  Try to do some basic things and you'll see that Amazon's services just fall on their face.  For instance, try getting a playlist imported from iTunes with Amazon Music Importer (of which only 250 songs are free to upload).  You can't - at least not preserving the order of the playlist (both Google and Microsoft have had apps that do this and keep things in tact for years - where has Amazon been?).  The apps that are available via Amazon's app store are only a smidgen of what is available in Google's Play Store.  And cloud storage is what Amazon is boasting about?  Please - both Google and Microsoft offer just as good if not better cloud-based services.  Stay away from this device at all costs.  Until Amazon learns how to write good software, their services and devices are going to continue to suffer (and you are going to have to deal with the pain).

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: I usually love Amazon products but this just isn't a good tablet.  My main issue is that you can't mirror image this wirelessly with FireTV.  It requires an additional micro HDMI cable and it's just inconvenient and a pain. This just doesn't make a lot of sense.  Why build something that doesn't have the same capabilities with FireTV as even my Android phone does?  I've read the HDX model is much better so maybe look at that one but if you've ever owned any other tablet, you're not going to like this one.  It's too basic.  I can see this one being good for travel or children but that's about it.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Very annoying. This one looks exactly like the last
review_body:
I am conflicted about this Fire HD. I had the last version, and it was starting to mess up- powering off by itself and not able to turn it back on for awhile, and if I was listening to music or watching a video, the sound would "click", and go way down if a friend posted something on Facebook. Very annoying.
This one looks exactly like the last, only with a camera added.
The bad part of this version is it won't play videos off of Facebook(the screen stays black), and the videos on You Tube that were fine on my old Fire look terrible, so I find myself frustrated . Even my very old phone has better quality video than this Fire. It might have something to do with no flash player anymore. I regret having bought it, but it was on sale, and the camera was a plus. I haven't tested it out to see if the camera visuals are as poor as the rest. If so, I will be really ticked off.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: This tablet is fast and works pretty well. For the price I paid its very hard to beat. The one thing I don't like about it is the way the UI works. There is no home button like on an apple device, so learning to use it takes some hunting around. It does have child profiles which is a bonus, but enabling that functionality further frustrates navigation. Just logging off one profile and onto another is not intuitive at all. You can log off the child profiles but there is no log off from the non-child profiles, you just lock the device, wake it up and then select the profile icon for the main user and then are presented with the other profiles as options. Very counter-intuitive. It would be better to have all profiles presented on the unlock screen. To Amazon's credit, the device pulled my kids profiles off my FireTV account with a single question/answer. Besides the UI issues which one can eventually learn, the device has excellent sound (stereo too), excellent screen resolution and color and snappy performance for games, video, browsing and other functions. I streamed a movie from my Prime account and it started instantly and ran smoothly and I have an older router and many wireless devices. I would give it 5 stars were it not for the clunky UI navigation issues. I suspect Amazon is not done tinkering with it and will probably introduce nav improvements. Even if they don't, once you get used to the way it works its a pretty good little tablet.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB

review_body: I do not need a tablet. I have had a Kindle reader for many years and that is what I have always been happy with. I am returning the Fire for a Paperwhite.

review_body: Very good tablet .love the resolution.Needs more GB or a Card Slot .  K.G.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: I bought one of these back when they first came out to replace a regular Fire and ended up sendingit back because it wasn't all that different from the original.  Just this week, with the super slashed price, I bought this newest generation and sent it back too.  It is just too bulky for me.  I would think that now, several years after the original Fire that technology would allow for a slimmer product.  I have an 8.9" Fire HD that is less bulky than this 7" one.  Strange, I know.  So, I'll just keep my trusty old original.  I can't really comment on HD screen comparison with non-HD because I only had it on briefly, maybe 5 minutes, I was that disappointed with it.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: OK, but I wouldn't buy it again
review_body:
This is the first tablet I ever bought. It has not been a great experience for me, but my four-year-old daughter enjoys it enough.

There are four main irritations: 1) the ever-present ads, 2) the lack of customization, 3) the slow wi-fi, and 4) the poor battery. Each and every time that either I or my daughter turns on the Kindle Fire HD, we get an ad that is very easy to click on. This is definitely not good for a young person who might take some time understanding what to click on. Users are not able to customize their interface very much. For example, I cannot put my favorite apps or videos or website on the home screen. Nor can users download apps from anywhere but Amazon, which really cuts down on the choices. The wi-fi is painfully slow at times. All the other wi-fi devices in our home work perfectly well, but the Kindle Fire HD creeps along, struggling to download apps and load webpages. Lastly, the battery life is just awful. We need to charge it after just about every use. This tablet cannot handle decent-sized games or many other apps.

Nevertheless, this tablet is a fun diversion for my four-year-old daughter. There are a few free games that we have found. They are age-appropriate and not filled with ads. We've bought a few apps, as well. In retrospect, I probably should have gone with a refurbished tablet that had a little more "umph" in it.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: My review is more for the support of Amazon then the product.  First I will say that the product seems to be a good product at a good price.  Purchased 2 tablets for our kids with the main purpose of gaming, music and music.  Pure toy for them with of course computer/tablet skills learning.  Tablets seem to do everything that they claim and as an adult function great.  2 issues however.  First, both original units charging ports went bad within 2 months.  For a product that you need to constantly charge day in day out this is not something that should fail.  Looking further into it this is a common issue with these units.  Was replaced and received new tablets.  Second, broken screen.  My son dropped his tablet and broke his screen (anybody who owns a phone or tablet knows this happens).  This is not covered by warranty (which i never asked for that BTW, but was told several times by amazon support) and amazon does not offer any support for a replacement/repair.  I was simply looking for a replacement screen to purchase and either replace myself or get replaced.  This I find confusing considering that this is a common issue in todays phone/tablet world with touch screens?  They will offer you a replacement tablet at a so called "reduced rate", but do not support their product with replacement or repair.  I guess you get what you payed for and amazon believes that these things are very disposable?  Nice job amazon!  So the moral is to do your research on everything before purchasing.  BUY LOCALLY too so that you can actually deal with a human.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Storage is not what it advertises.
review_body: I just got my Fire today and I'm actually highly disappointed in it.  First off, I knew I should have gone with the larger size, but I tried to save a little money and go with the 8GB. The problem is, I barely installed one game before it announced my Fire was using 90% of it's space. I went into the settings to discover that it said I was using 3.5GB and I have 1.56GB remaining. Not to mention that as I am writing this, a new message popped up saying the game it was trying to install is 1.50GB and I only have 1.15GB remaining while behind the message it clearly says 1.56GB free in the storage settings. Regardless of of the .35 difference.. 3.5 + 1.56 does NOT equal 8GB.. not to mention that the apps I installed equaled to less than 2GB... VERY disappointed that this Fire does not have the space it is supposed to have and is very inconsistent with the storage it does have. I'd like to also point out that I went in and deleted apps I installed and it went from saying my used space was 3.50 to 3.81 and my free space went from 1.50 to 1.25 AFTER I deleted content from the device!  EDIT: I went back and restored the Kindle to factory defaults. I have done absolutely nothing to the device except turn it on and make sure the software was up to date and I am showing that I have 4.28GB of free space. This is only half of what it should be. Of course, customer service said that the other half is taken up by the OS, but then it should be advertised as 4GB because that is all the user is getting. I don't care how much space the OS has to take up.

YouTube no longer works on that device and is no longer available in the Amazon App store.  There was a great sale on the Fire HD 7 and I hoped that more apps would be supported on the newer device. But they are not. In my opinion, the Fire HD is no better as a reader and no more useable as a tablet than my old Kindle Fire. I did sideload several apps immediately after receiving the device, including YouTube, but that app any many others require Google Services which is not supported by the OS. I was able to sideload Flash so that I could sideload the Closeli app for a camera (bought the camera through Amazon but the app is not available in the Amazon store).  Honestly, I knew the device would come with the Fire OS but thought they might have become a bit more progressive.  Perhaps the Fire HD has a lot of bang for the buck but without root it is really nothing but a poor reading device.  I love Amazon but I'm not feeling it with the Fire HD7.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body:
Let's get this out of the way right now: the Fire HD 7 does not compare well against any of its pricier competitors, and that's mostly due to Amazon's extremely limited Fire OS. If you're looking for a truly full featured tablet experience, you would be better served looking at an iPad or a more expensive Android device running a proper version of the operating system.

This is device that's defined in many ways by what you can't do. You can't download apps from the Google Play store. There isn't a default Youtube app. There's relatively poor support for common third-party services like Dropbox, and accessing Google services is either impossible or requires workarounds. You can't even use and login to Chrome without going through a process that's likely to seem daunting to non-technical users. And if you are one of those technical users, don't expect to be able to root a 4th gen Fire to turn it into a proper Android device. It's not happening.

That said, the Fire is competent in its own little niche. The device pops out of sleep quickly and Fire OS is a smooth and fairly seamless experience. I haven't had any crashes or other oddities that diminish the experience. Unsurprisingly, it works flawlessly if you're mainly interested in making use of Amazon services like Prime streaming or Kindle books. Amazon's app store has only a fraction of the apps that are available on Google Play (and many popular or common ones are missing), but the selection isn't terrible and there's a good mix of software for most basic needs.

The hardware itself ranges from "pretty good" to "god awful." The quad core processor, at this price point, is a nice piece of kit. It's good enough to make the Fire HD feel snappier and more responsive than a cheap budget table has any right to be. The screen is a high point as well. The pixel density on the 7" version isn't spectacular, but it looks fine and the overall quality is good. The case is cheap feeling plastic with a textured matte finish. It's not terrible, but you'll be disappointed if you're used to higher quality tablets or phones. The cameras are so terrible that they border on useless. They're acceptable (barely) if you only intend to use them for video chat, but expect photo quality that's on par with ten year old feature phones. They're that bad.

On the whole, the Fire HD is decidedly unimpressive. It feels like there's a great budget device here, but the limitations mean that it never crosses over that magical line that turns it into a great value. You get exactly what you pay for, and at this price that's fine. Just don't expect to be blown away or to receive a device that'll give tablets costing twice as much a run for their money.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Nowhere Even Close to Fire TV's Level of Quality
review_body:
I'm a huge fan of Amazon's Fire TV, so I expected to be blown away by the company's tablet offerings. I mean, Amazon's tablets seem to be immensely popular, while virtually no one I've spoken to locally even knows that the Fire TV is, so surely these tablets are solid, right? Well, while I've only had the Fire HD 7 for a day, and I know that the right software update could make a ton of difference in the future, this review is based on my initial experience with the device, and that experience is anything but positive.

Now, for the pluses and minuses:

+ The display, while not full HD, is actually quite nice.

- Getting a movie that you downloaded over Wi-Fi to play offline isn't as intuitive as it should be. Unless I'm doing something wrong, launching a movie offline when you've already downloaded it seems to only work from the carousel. Trying to play it anywhere else just generates an error, and even launching from the carousel makes it seem like the device is locked up. (There's no indication that it's loading the movie. The UI just becomes completely unresponsive until playback begins. This isn't the case on Fire TV.)
- Haptic feedback would've been nice. The UI just feels lifeless and lacks sufficient feedback to your input, in my opinion.
- The carousel UI is a colossal waste of space.
- The UI generally just needs more context menus (ideally by long-pressing).
- These tablets don't have nearly enough storage for what they are. They should've had SD card support. Sure, I don't *have* to download HD versions of my movies to watch offline, but I should have the option to do so, because I bought HD movies in order to watch them in HD. Being able to only download three HD movies onto this thing (16 GB version - thank God I didn't settle for the 8 GB version) before it's too full for another download is just ridiculous. Speaking of which, the menu for managing storage shouldn't be buried in settings. You should be able to long-press on a movie from anywhere on the UI and delete it.

Yes, I understand that Fire TV is plugged in and isn't relying on battery power, but there's no reason for the Fire tablet experience to be this much worse than the Fire TV experience. I'll update my review if things improve in the future, but I can't help but feel that the experience simply won't get that much better. While I realize that it'd be at the expense of app compatibility, I honestly wish that Amazon would dump Android and work with something more lightweight for the underlying OS. This thing feels like an Android tablet...and not an especially good one.able to long-press on a movie from anywhere on the UI and delete it.

Yes, I understand that Fire TV is plugged in and isn't relying on battery power, but there's no reason for the Fire tablet experience to be this much worse than the Fire TV experience. I'll update my review if things improve in the future, but I can't help but feel that the experience simply won't get that much better. While I realize that it'd be at the expense of app compatibility, I honestly wish that Amazon would dump Android and work with something more lightweight for the underlying OS. This thing feels like an Android tablet...and not an especially good one.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: Update 5/7/2015: This thing is getting more frustrating by the day. It's already giving me warnings that it's nearly full. I guess that's partially my fault for getting the 8GB version....but I never imagined i'd be able to nearly fill this thing with just a few children's apps. They shouldn't even sell the thing with this low of a capacity.   It's still very dodgy performance....sometimes it's speedy, but most of the time it's slow. Still take a ridiculous amount of time to download an app. THIS alone has cause both me and my daughter a great deal of frustration (kids aren't known to be that patient as it is).   The app selection is horrible for the child subscription service that's offered....free time unlimited?!? WHAT A JOKE...it's VERY limited. Majority of the apps are low low low quality. Very few truly educational apps. And once again...they take forever to download and install.   Another quirk is that some apps, even though they are child centric, still have to be installed from the adult profile. But the thing is...when you download it from the adult profile, and then add it to the kids profile, it appears that you have to redownload it. No clue WHAT that's about. So you ultimately have to wait twice as long now before you can finally allow your child to play the app.   The sluggishness of downloading apps means you really have to plan ahead and curate apps for your child way ahead of when they're going to actually play on the thing. This is very frustrating because the apps on the children's profile literally offer NO description of exactly what they are. So you have to select the app, WAIT for it to download...THEN open the app and determine if it's an app you even want or that your child will even enjoy! THIS is beyond frustrating and really really kills the enjoyment of the device for the parent and the child.   I really want to return this thing and purchase a table that has regular old Android OS on it. But despite it's many many many many flaws....mychild would have a fit if it wasn't around. Hopefully I can do a switcheroo on her but i'll have to find a green bumper case so she's none the wiser....well....she'll probably be wise to it VERY quick once she sees how much better it is.   I feel horrible that I recommended this thing to so many parents before I even owned one myself. That was definitely irresponsible of me :( ... It might explain some of the dirty looks i've been getting.    Original Review Below Here: Purchased this for the sole purpose of giving it to my toddler. Kid's mode is NOT at all what it's billed to be. The primary problem is that the app store is still fully accessible to the child and they'll spend more time download each and every app that they see instead of playing with the apps that you've installed for them. It's frustrating that there's no way to preview and see exactly what the app IS when you're in the kid's mode too. It also takes a ridiculous amount of time to download the apps! SO FRUSTRATING!  The next HUGE deal breaker is that you have to REPURCHASE apps you've already purchased from the Google Play Store. The same freaking apps! I have rebuy all these child focused apps that i'd already purchased for our little one to play with on my Android phone and tablet. This is beyond infuriating. Amazon really needs to come up with a way for their app store to cohabitate with the Google Play Store. No one should have to repurchase the same apps for the same platform simply because Amazon doesn't want to put the Google Play Store onto their devices. And no, I don't want to/shouldn't have to root my device just to do something that should be provided as an option.  Getting out of kid's mode is NOT intuitive or easy. You have to push the power button off and then back on to get to the lock screen, then select the adult profile you want to use.  It's a really sluggish device overall. The FireOS skin (i REFUSE to call it an operating system because it's simply a clunky skin on top of Android) is very unintuitive and slow. So you browse apps, touch the app, and then wait....and wait....and wait....and wait....for it to finally download. Oh yeah, no 5Ghz wifi band use here....only 2.4Ghz......  Everything is SO SLOW. I don't understand it. It shouldn't be this sluggish based on the specs.  Lucky I got it on sale for seventy nine dollars.....I'd be really upset had I paid full retail. NO ONE should pay full retail for this thing.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Storage space not even close to advertised.
review_body:
Initial presentation, fantastic. Speed and responsiveness, spectacular. Build quality, awesome. Screen crispness, wunderbar.
Why only two stars? I understand 8gb formatted is approximately 7.37gb usable. I understand I can expect a gig of OS and bloatware. But when I first booted the device, the storage capacity showed as 0.95GB used for OS and bloatware, and 4.11GB free. 4.11gb + 0.95gb = 5.06gb. Where is my remaining 7.37gb-5.06gb=2.31gb worth of space? That's huge when you're only starting with "8gb." I called in to Amazon who explained that the remaining 2.31gb was additional hidden system resources.

I purchased this with the understanding that I had limited space, and more than likely had room for only one 720p HD movie at a time, which would be approximately 5gb. Negative.

I also purchased this during a deal promotion. I overnighted the Fire to myself for a trip today. Amazon would not let me purchase a 16gb version at the promotion price since the promotion was ended.

Talk about false advertising. Of all the things I do with amazon - buy, sell, prime, prime video, prime music, etc. This is a top 10 sore spot for me.

Buyer beware - 8gb is actually 4.15gb usable.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Worked okay, I guess, just not for me
review_body: This seriously wasn't for me and I am returning it.  I'm sure it works as advertised and as it's supposed to but after almost seven days I've decided the frustration isn't worth it.  I was looking for something more like my smartphone without the phone aspect per se.  The HD screen was beautiful and I watched many of my favorite YouTube music videos on it but that really isn't a good enough reason to keep it.  It was pretty okay for playing games (for the most part) but kind of an expensive tool for doing what I can on my PC and smartphone.  The last straw was when one of the games I purchased was replaced with something else from the same game developer without warning.  That obviously had nothing to do with this Fire but I took it as a sign that this was not meant to be.  I just felt this was to clunky regarding the applications and OS for what I was looking for.  It did feel sturdy and it arrived much sooner than expected regarding shipping (would give 10 stars for that), but again, it wasn't for me.  I think for smaller kids or people not so much into web surfing, browsing, shopping, and simple functions, et cetera it would be perfect.

review_headline: A downgrade from the Fire HD in build quality and video playback.
review_body: After my Fire 7 met it's demise face first onto a hardwood floor, I bought the new "improved" Fire HD 7 to replace it. The build quality of the Fire HD 7 is horrendous, it creaks and cracks wherever I hold it on it's much thicker and cheaper plastic back. In addition, whenever I stream videos on the unit I get video corruption or slowdown until I reboot the device on to have it happen again shortly thereafter. I've reset it to factory settings twice but the issues ensue and that won't help the build quality lacking regardless. This does not feel like an upgrade or suitable replacement to the old Fire HD, it feels like a cheap letdown product urging you to buy the HDX instead.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Check the tech details for ACTUAL available space
review_body:
Don't buy this but if you must, get the larger size. Amazon hogs 3.5 GB (4.4 on the 16GB) for its operating system and the applications it loads on it and doesn't give you ANY ability to modify it.

Check out the technical details - it lists the actual size available to user right there: 8 GB (4.5 GB available to user) or 16 GB (11.6 GB available to user) of internal storage.

They want you to stream everything but that's only possible when you have wifi. Forget loading a bunch of stuff on here for traveling. & when you get close to storage limit, it shuts off your wifi. Search the forums. The lack of space (& "junk" you can't find to clean up) is a major problem.

I'm sure it will be useful at home to watch streaming video in rooms that don't have TV. Also, I like the Kindle e-reader well enough. It's just not the travel companion I was expecting. I'm sure it would do a better job if it was better at connecting to the hot spots. This trip has given me more reasons to brag about my cheap smartphone.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Parental controls miss the mark and make the tablet pointless for older kids
review_body:
Would return this if we could. The parental controls look great. They apparently provide a degree of control and flexibility unavailable elsewhere and yet they miss the mark in unforgivable ways.

A child account is completely unable to use a web browser under any circumstances and is also unable to use email. I cannot understand why these cannot be enabled but they make the device useless for schoolwork and undermine the value of the tablet. Don't think about switching your child to an adult account because Amazon family accounts can only have two adults in them. Grown up children at home? Tough. Trying to fix the shortcomings of parental controls? Also tough. The only option is to create a standalone account that cannot share any content. Might as well have bought a standard android tablet or a cheap kindle reader. The former would do what the fire should do while the latter will more cheaply do what the fire is actually usable for.

Extremely disappointed because a small number of fundamental software design decisions completely ruin the device.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: I ordered this in January after leaving my Kindle Fire HD on a plane. I loved my Kindle and what I loved most about it was how long the battery lasted. I could travel knowing I would be able to read, watch a movie, or maybe play a game - and that I could leave my charger at home.  I ordered the replacement under the assumption that the battery life would be roughly the same, if not better, but this is not the case. I don't know if it applies to all of this model or if my Kindle is flawed, but the battery life is horrible and drains very quickly. I now have to travel with the charger because I am not confident that the battery will last more than a few hours. It has been a few months and I finally had to voice my dissatisfaction with my new Kindle. Not only do I like the old model's shape better (it was more round - this generation is boxy and the case I loved and even ordered won't fit on this model so I had to order a different, less attractive case) but I also am not happy with the battery life. Therefore I cannot give this product a high rating.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: I would pick one with mayday -- basic support isn't enough if you have an issue
review_body:
I have bought every fire tablet either for myself or for my family. I have to say this is the one I liked the least. I loved the color options, but after I put it in its cover it didn't seem to matter. It wasn't faster or slower than my older fire.

It seems to have issues staying charged. Without a Mayday button all the support I seemed to receive was suggestions to reboot the thing -- didn't help.

I just ordered another one, but one with mayday. I hope my next kindle makes me as happier than this one did.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: When considering the cost- know that you will need to replace it on an annual basis
review_body:
I have a love/ hate relationship with kindles. I have purchased seven over the years and four of them have died right after the one year warranty has ended. Please consider the life expectancy when making your purchase. The last one I had looks brand new, and was kept in a amazon case constantly and was never dropped or damaged ever and now it is stuck on the kindle fire screen and there is nothing customer service will do, other than to offer a measly $15 off a replacement.
If you don't mind replacing them on an annual basis they are an amazing product.

review_headline: I'll have to go to an IPAD or something better! Amazon had me reset the kindle to its ...
review_body: I am going to have to send the kindle back and I haven't even had it for two weeks!  It constantly shuts itself off or freezes up and I have to power it down!  I book that I was loaned from another person's kindle was available on my OLD kindle but would NOT download on the NEW kindle!  This is my 4th kindle in about 5 years.  The replacement one will probably be my last. I'll have to go to an IPAD or something better!  Amazon had me reset the kindle to its "factory settings" after my first complaint.  I then had to reload all of my apps. I do not want to do that again, but feel like I have no choice.  It's just frustrating!  And seriously, Amazon can't include a plug in to the kindle charger?!?!?

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: We HATE, HATE, HATE this tablet. If you are purchasing this as a tablet for your child DON'T DO IT! We purchased this back in December along with freetime for our daughter to be able to watch a few shows, work with apps, and read. The "system" takes up well over half of the storage. She barely has anything loaded on this tablet and every 5 minutes it turns off the wi-fi connection because of "critically low storage" There is almost nothing left to remove from the device to free up storage so that it will continue to work. This is a great disappointment.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: I liked my old one better.  The screen display is very nice but when my hands are cold (which they are frequently) the screen wont move for me.  My otter case from my old kindle  fire(no hd). will not work with it and I had to buy a new one.  The old Kindle had a weakness at the charging port which they appear to have corrected. Time will tell.  It has been less than one month since I got it. I was able to download an use some better game apps and the kids apps do work better on the new HD.  I just cant let the kids walk around with it because there is no Otter for it. This model is not enough better to justify buying if your old Kindle Fire is still working but mine had a charging problem.  (somtimes it will charge and sometimes it wont).

review_body: DO NOT BUY A KINDLE. it truly isn't worth it. I bought mine and amazon customer service have been great help but the device itself is awful and frustrating to work with. It's extremely slow, and I really don't use more than the internet to surf and browse or youtube to watch videos. I have no large files or videos stored and I see no reason whatsoever for it being so slow. It's so frustrating trying to browse because the internet pages keep freezing . It took me a while we're I just gave up on using it and turned to my phone. Ugh I truly regret this purchase .

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: I am really pleased with this tablet, which is my first. I didn't want to start with a more expensive tablet, then find out I wouldn't really use it. It's been fun figuring out what it can do and there are a lot of things I haven't even tried yet. The biggest use for me is reading books; I was a little disappointed to sign up for Kindle Unlimited and then discover I can only have 10 books at a time. I like being able to check my email without having to go to my home office and get on my computer. I also like being able to get to the internet. The camera is not the greatest, but that is not a big deal for me. The visual clarity is great. One thing I want to do that I haven't got to yet is to hook this up to my TV to watch downloaded movies. This a a comfortable size, but I can already see that down the road I am going to want something a little bigger. I think this tablet is a great deal for the price even if the ads from Amazon when you first open it are a little annoying.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body:
This HD7 kindle is my second fire. I had the first generation as soon as it came out. So far, I love that the charging port has been moved to the top. I have always felt that all my issues with the charging port on the first edition were due to the port being on the bottom and getting abuse when I would read and rest the bottom on my stomach while charging.

Time will tell if it truly fixes the weakness.

Screen sharpness and clarity plus the fantastic sound are definite pluses over my kids' iPad minis. I also find the kindle more user friendly and love the carousel on the main page.

So far I recommend the kindle fire Hd 7 as a much better tablet than the iPad mini.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: About time!  A tablet that thinks it's a giant.
review_body:
IF you are on the fence, Please, don't go by the negative reviews here. Many of the reviewers are nitpicking, and did not read, before purchasing, the specs this tablet offers. Familiarize yourself with what this tablet can and cannot do, and you are more than halfway to an informed decision as to whether to buy or not. Then you can decide based on YOUR needs from a well-made tablet.

This tablet is zippy! The battery life is very good (let the tablet die out, then charge and do that again for improved battery life). The speakers give a good sound to your movies and music; with headphones, this tablet rocks (I suggest buy N7 music player)!

The screen is gorgeous for such a low-end tablet, and will make movies pop, text stand clear and your overall enjoyment a pleasure. If you don't lose sight of the fact that this is an under $150 tablet (7" model), you will enjoy this well-made tablet.
