product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Got this for my daughter's birthday...
review_body:
Worked ok for the first day.

Set it up... which was a pain. As compared to my iPad, it was slooooow. Apps work great and relatively quick. Trying to navigate settings is irritating and painful. Integration with Amazon is awesome though. Free-Play is the feature that made the fire so attractive to me, and I wasn't disappointed... at least not right away.

After the first day the WiFi randomly decided to shut off. Trying to access settings, it just says "Turning Wi-Fi on..." but nothing happens. I can't adjust any account settings on it, so my daughters are sharing an account to use the few apps that were loaded onto it beforehand. No videos, and no more books. Since Free-Play depends heavily on internet access, my daughter spends more time playing with her other birthday presents than with the Fire.

It's ok that Amazon disappointed me. But my wife and kids are not patient when dealing with the frustration. My daughters are now asking if they can return the Fire and get an iPad Mini... "Because your iPad works and the Fire can't do anything."

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: I love my Fire HD7!  I had an 2gen Fire but I wanted one that I could load more items on and that had a better reading screen for outside. With my new Fire, I can keep so many items accessible to me on the unlimited cloud and they have improved the screen glare so that I can now read and play games much better outside. The Fire is lighting fast in all actions and especially in downloading items or downloading items back and forth from the cloud when I need them. I also love the camera, which I didn't have in the older version. It takes nice clear pictures and between the cloud and the device, I'm able to store over 600 pictures. I now use my Fire especially on vacations, so I don't have to carry my laptop. I have access to my email, Facebook, Netflix, and any movies and pictures I want to see. I can even open (not edit) some of my personal files thru my Dropbox account.  I play casino games extensively on my Fire and the graphics are so bright and the game moves lightening fast with no lags. Love, Love, this Fire. I bought a Samsung Galaxy Tab 4 first, but I returned it because it lagged too much in viewing my pictures on the SD card, and I had to restart it many times when playing my games. I have had none of these issues with my FIRE.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: meh, okay but a little hobbled Update- get something else
review_body: I got this for my wife to watch Netflix and Amazon videos. Certainly better price than a full tablet. She ended up not liking it so I inherited it. I think Amazon is trying to replicate the walled garden approach used so successfully by Apple. However, with those products one is able to at least be productive. Forget ANY Google apps- there are none in the Amazon app store. There isn't even my top-rated password manager. On the plus side the screen is crisp and the OS solid. If you want to shop Amazon and watch videos and not much else, this is a great tablet to do just those things. If Amazon would allow those major apps, I suspect they would sell a lot more of these without having to discount the price to move them off the shelves.  UPDATE- After having used this almost daily for several months, I have to take off another star. We buy *a lot* of stuff from Amazon and this tablet excels at that and not much else. If something pops into my head and I need to email, text or edit a 'to do' list, I have to set this down and go to a computer or my phone to accomplish it. What an inconvenience in this day and age. It's okay for watching Amazon Prime movies or Netflix (I'm surprised they even support this app!), but several other free movie apps are missing. If I had to do it over again I wouldn't buy this (even though there are some pluses listed above), but would spend the few extra dollars to have a fully operational tablet. They made the same mistake with the Fire phone (from what I read) and sales are dismal. I imagine people aren't waiting in line for these either. Spend the money and get something with the apps that 95% us use.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: My girlfriend bought me this tablet as a gift because I had mentioned I wanted a tablet for reading. First impressions were it was a solid tablet and much better than previous ones I tried using. After about 2 months I accidently fell asleep in bed with it and upon waking up it fell about 2ft to a carpeted floor and the touch screen stopped working completely. I contacted Amazon about replacing the screen and since the design they used it is not like other tablets on the market where the screen can be replaced. So I am stuck paying almost market value to have the screen replaced which is kind of pointless. I was really expecting a better design granted it was my mistake that lead to its demise. I just want everyone to be aware of this prior to purchasing.   **********UPDATE 3/17/2015*********  Spoke with Amazon customer service today (associates name was Indira) and she resolved the issue I previously had with my Kindle fire. I am updating my previous review of 2 stars to 5 stars for outstanding customer service and Amazon standing by their product and really helping out their customers. Thank you Amazon.

Instead of going through the hassle of replacing the second device I  decided to get an upgrade and let my grand kids have the older one. product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: I already had one that I have been using for a little over a year.  My Eddie was very jealous (although he is the one who bought it for me) so I had to get him one for Christmas.  It is a great device for the price that you pay and meets all of my expectations and needs.  I mainly use it as an eReader but do use it for checking e-mails, etc. when I do not have access to my laptop (on vacation, etc.).  It loads quickly, has a huge amount of storage, and allows me to carry everything I need in one hand.  The back lighting (which my first Kindle did not have) is great.  The battery holds up for a long time provided I do not keep the WiFi turned on all the time.  What more could a girl ask for?

review_headline: cheapo - compared to earlier model Kindles
review_body:
This review is rated as JUST OKAY because I am comparing it to the former Kindle Fire. Bought this because my beloved earlier model Kindle Fire's port quit taking a charge. Kind of ticked because the original one THAT I LOVED was just fine except the charging port mysteriously quit, so I was basically forced to buy another one - how convenient for Amazon - right?
This model is disappointing to me because it just does not seem to have to same oomph as my former one - although I cant quite put my finger on the problem. The outer shell, although strong, gives it a cheap feel. Also disappointing that the size changed just enough where I cannot use my older protector covers. I basically just disappointed - if I would have known there would be so many disappointments, I might have looked in to purchasing something different.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: Buy it, if only to ensure your electronics are covered by great customer service. I had ordered a 6. There was a problem with it and it needed to be returned. The replacement was backordered for weeks. Amazing Amazon customer service upgraded me to a 7 and it had been perfect. The magenta color is bright and fun. Though I don't like silk browser, I had gotten used to it on my original Fire so it doesn't have any more irksome issues than than before. The reader will now search Wikipedia and the internet when using the dictionary feature which is nice. My husband spent hundreds on an Ipad mini, and I find him frequently stealing my Fire instead. It really is the best value out there.

review_headline: Great pad, Great price.  You can't go wrong with the Kindle Fire.
review_body: I've had the Kindle Fire for a couple weeks now and I admit it is much better than the previous kindle I had.  The battery life is under rated.  While Amazon says 8 hr battery life, I've had no problems pushing it to 8.5/9 hrs.  The body has a cheap feel and look, but with a nice case that is irrevalent.  The connection on WiFi is fast.  Signing on is a breeze.  Since I'm single I didn't need the free time app that comes installed, but it would be great for limiting time for kids.  The speakers work very well and don't sound bad.  I've hooked the Fire up to a set of portable speakers I use for my MP3 and it works well. Overall this is a great pad for gaming, reading or just surfing the net while away from your computer.  I highly recommend purchasing the Kindle Fire 7 inch.  The price is better than the competition and it performs as well as other pads.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Does not live up to hype.. APPS are pretty pathetic.
review_body:
I am a die-hard Amazon fan but to be honest I am not a fan of the kindle fire hd7. I bought two HD7's and two HD6's. (Myself,wife,2 kids) and from the start we had problems. First they were constantly dropping the Wi-Fi signal. I finally called Amazon and they said it was my router. I upgraded the router software and it did work. I was frustrated that out of the hundred items that I use Wi-Fi with, the kindles all had issues with my router.

Now my biggest complaint is not being able to use google play for my APPS. I understand competition but Amazon's selection is horrible compared to Google's. Also the aps that Amazon does have are garbage. Even their own Amazon app is bad. Half of the time I put down my kindle and grab my smartphone to use the same aps that I have on my kindle(and the thousand other apps that Amazon does not have).

It really sucks because my Fire is turning into expensive paper weights. Amazon is awesome but I would recommend staying away from the fire until Amazon gets serious with their APPS. Go with Apple or google instead.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Okay For Tight Budgets and Kids, Otherwise Consider Something Else
review_body: Bought two of these for my kids to save money versus iPads.  And while I won't say I regret it completely, the Kindles leave a lot to be desired in both functionality and ease of use relative to an iPad.  One of the two devices crashes routinely or freezes and has to be completely rebooted.  The device menu and help pages tend to be non-intuitive and not pleasant to use.  Supposedly, you can also drag and drop music and movie files on the devices but I can't get them to play with sound on either device in various encoding formats..  I also have experienced significant trouble connecting to certain WiFi networks - especially on airplanes, which is when I really needed them to function properly the most.  Lastly, the online help available is less than helpful - if the topic you're searching for even exists in the first place.  I generally find better help by Googling third party message boards.  Conclusion: If you're on a tight budget like I was when I bought them, or you're seeking devices for younger kids/children, then they're passable.  However, if you have the money or you need to be a serious tablet user, I'd opt for considering the substantially more expensive iPad.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: the volume button quickly stopped working despite going to great lengths to make sure it was well taken care ...
review_body:
we have had two different kindles; a regular kindle and a kindle fire. neither one lasted very long before they had to be returned.
the volume button quickly stopped working despite going to great lengths to make sure it was well taken care of and has a thick protective case. . when i called amazon to have it taken care of, i was informed that if you put your kindle(any of the many different types) in a bag; book bag or computer bag etc, it is not covered by the warranty, I was shocked... what do they think people are going to do? carry them in their hands all the time? perhaps they should have a better plan to carry their product around or better yet, make a product that works better. we have an extended warranty on ours but i will never buy another kindle again. : (

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: I expected to really like this tablet -- my first "smart" device other than ...
review_body:
I expected to really like this tablet -- my first "smart" device other than my laptop. I expected to primarily use it on the road, so I could read books without bulk and check email and Facebook at hotspots. What I didn't expect was to be able to record choral rehearsals or download an app to help me manage my calorie intake. I've found much to enjoy about this gizmo, beyond expectations, and so it gets the "love it!" five stars from me.

Just one regret: I should have coughed up the extra $15 to avoid all the special offers that pop up when I'm using the thing with Wi-Fi. The good news about that is that I can still pay $15 to put a stop to it, and plan to do so as soon as I remember how.

Yeah, there's a learning curve for a dino like me, but I'm mostly enjoying the process. It's supposed to be good for older brains to learn whole new skills, so it's all good.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: Love that books are downloaded quickly and that wifi is not needed to read downloaded books or to play downloaded games.  Love that the reading screen (for books) has both an adjustable background (so that it isn't so bright) and adjustable fonts for easy reading if you've forgotten your glasses. The touch screen is very responsive and the format is easy to use.  The only con about this Fire is that Facebook is an app and what is posted there is completely different than what is on the FB website.  But that is more of an app issue than device issue.  I love this Fire and it's simple compact design.  Can't wait to take it on vacation!  I'll be saving a lot of space by not having to lug my books and laptop with me!

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: spend the extra dollars and buy something better like a Samsung
review_body: I purchased this tablet for my daughter as a Christmas present and was very disappointed. It is a poorly designed tablet that is extremely difficult to navigate and use. If it wasn't for the ability to use Amazon Instant videos I would have given it a one star rating. Believe me, you are better off spending the extra 30bucks and buying a Galaxy tablet. There aren't any buttons to easily return to your home screen and if you plan on giving this as a gift to a child and trying to use the parental controls, get ready for major headaches. You'll end up having to create two profiles, one for yourself and the child and then switching between the two to use the device. I even tried returning it but Amazon doesnt accept returns on this product. They wont even allow you to sell it back on their services. This tablet shuts off randomly, has a hard time connecting to wi-fi and doesn't hold a charge either. The one positive is the screen is really nice.

review_body: This was a gift from a friend.  I love it!  The display is super sharp.  It was very easy to set up and get on to using it immediately. There are plenty of \\"free\\" apps to download for games, etc.  I also have a Kindle Paperwhite just for reading, but those books, etc., load up on my Kindle Fire HD also, so where I leave off reading of my book on the Paperwhite, it's right there on the Fire HD so I only have to carry the one tablet with me.  I love this tablet.  You can even print from it to a wireless printer.  I love dealing with Amazon.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Not recognized by Windows XP Pro SP3
review_body: This device is obviously designed for use with the newer versions of Windows. Even when you follow Amazon's instructions for connecting with XP - download/install Windows Media Player 11, say the magic words three times backwards, dance with a armadillo in a clown suit at midnight - no joy - drivers don't load; this Kindle will not connect. Check the tech blogs and see that this is a known issue for Kindle Fire/Windows XP. Be helpful if Amazon said that up front. But the Kindle Fire (HD7) is recognized by Ubuntu, so it won't need to return to Amazon - so far.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: I think that the home screen is an easy access way to get around
review_body:
Dear Amazon,

I have had my Kindle for awhile now and I am a big fan of it. I think that the home screen is an easy access way to get around. There are an abundance of neat features. However I have come up with a list of features which I think would be really cool to have and frankly I think they are a necessity.

First off, wallpapers! Please make it to where you can at least have a home screen wallpaper! The gray, bleak default is quite boring. So please Amazon make this an option. I believe that this would male your customers very happy. I personally Would love to have a wallpaper. And if you can also make it to where the non adult versions of the Kindle to have a lock screen wallpaper.

A second thing that I would like to see is more animations. Make the os more appealing to the eye. Create animations for opening folders and opening apps.

Amazon stop being apple and allow more customazation.

Reach out to more app developers and make the App Store more wide in variety. If you want, even consider adding the Google Play store to the device.

Here is a suggestion for a new multitasking interface. When you slide up from the bar at the bottom, instead of just the apps showing, show pictures of what you were last doing in that app. The name off the app would be on top of the image with the app icon next to it. Have it to where when you tap the app, it enlarges from that point and fills up your screen.

now lastly I would like to see a new notification bar. Let users customize the color of it. Make it similar to Android lollipop where if you Swype on the left, you get notifications and on the right quick settings.

Also in the settings add a search feature and a recently used feature

Thank you for reading,

Kelby's Bricker

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: all this would've been fine and dandy if not for their TV ads implying ...
review_body: I bought this for my daughter for Christmas.  Recently she dropped it from about 3 feet (she's 3' 11" tall) onto it's display flat onto grass.  The screen shattered.  I find out about it after my daughter slices her finger on the crazed but still functioning display.  "Hmm... These things happen", I say to myself.  But then I watch the latest TV commercial on this Fire HD 7 and it show a hapless mom forgetting her Fire 7 she left on top of her van and watch as her fire 7 flies off and hits the concrete right on the display screen but lo and behold!  Not a scratch!!  What gives?!  I called kindle fire customer support and refer to their implications in the TV commercial ad.  They refuse to acknowledge it and tell me that I'm now out of warranty and that I should've plunked down an additional $29.99 in accident protection.  Additionally, they offer to sell me a refurbished Fire HD 7 for $105 (new is $139.99).  Well, all this would've been fine and dandy if not for their TV ads implying non existent product toughness.  Shame on Amazon for their deceptive advertising!  I think from now on I will look elsewhere for a sturdier tablet.

review_body:
I really enjoy using my New Kindle Fire HD 7. The graphics are great and the sound quality is awesome.

The only thing I'm not really happy with is the Read-to-Me function while reading Kindle ebooks. It is really strange when the word is "it's" and it says "it" then it says "s". It also reads the symbols << and >> as "less than less than greater than greater than". It doesn't sound like a computer speaking, but it doesn't sound quite right either. The pauses between words and phrases isn't exactly right.

I hope they come up with a software update to correct the Read-to-Me feature.

This Kindle was a gift from my Daughter. I had given one to my son a couple of years ago and he really enjoys his.

On a scale of 1 - 5, I give it a "10" !!!!

review_headline: TERRIBLE PRODUCT, your crazy if you buy
review_body: I bought my kids 4 kindles for Christmas only to discover that the wifi does not work. I have several TV's, computers, iphones, and ipads that are all connected to the same wifi, but the Kindles wouldn't work. After a month of going back and forth with Kindle technical support and reading more and more reviews with the same issue, I returned the Kindles only to discover a $22.80 restocking fee per Kindle($91.20). I spoke to several customer service representatives who only said sorry that's our policy. So Kindle charged me almost a hundred dollars for a lot of frustration and time, to find out that there product is junk. Well your policy has lost a Kindle client for life and I own two others that are being thrown away, so no more ancillary product purchases from me. I will be purchasing 4 ipad mini's since Kindle is clearly a way inferior product and flat out doesn't work.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Good - looking forward to even more improvements in the future.
review_body:
Good but the longer I have it, the more I'd like to improve. I purchased the Fire 7" when my Kindle Touch suddenly bit the dust. First, it's main purpose - that of reading Kindle books and occasionally listening to an audio book - works well and my only complaints are: 1.) it's slow - 3 minutes to load 11 books on my device. 2.) One cannot delete books from the Fire - you have to go online to do so. That's poor planning. 3.) One cannot successfully do two things at once - such as listening to music while browsing Pinterest.

Those are just a few of my disappointments with my fire. Still, if someone were to give me the choice again today I'd make the same choice. It's a good price for what the tablet is able to do. The Kindle reader is handy and I like the things now available such as seing the table of contents on the left (if you wish), being able to group books in your library in "collections", and unlimited storage on the cloud.

It's good and I'm looking forward to positive changes in the future.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: It's a Kiindle Fire!  Means it's great.
review_body:
When I call my Kindle Fire a life changing item, I really mean it. I no longer buy books made of paper. The void left by the lack of book clutter has not gone empty - oh no. That void has been filled nicely with stuff. But I digress. This version of Kindle Fire places the buttons back in a more intuitive spot. The power and volume buttons are on the edge instead of the back. To me, this makes sense but I can't explain why. The speakers are on the back. Tiny little things that point away from the user. It's fine I guess since a lot of people use ear buds. The screen resolution is beautiful, the interface is simple. Set up is fast and easy too. Probably the only thing I don't like is the alarm feature volume is so quiet. I didn't hear this alarm go off and it was 4 feet away from me. Don't expect to wake up with this alarm. I do like the option to add a user. Now my hubby can borrow my Kindle Fire and not have his settings replace my own.

I love my Kindle Fire. My hubby benefits since he gets my older one. My mother-in law got his older one. Since I'm likely to keep buying the next greatest thing I just wish the cases were universal so I wouldn't have to buy new ones. But I guess that's part of the genius that is Amazon, I keep buying.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Doesn't stand up to my Kindle Fire 8.9
review_body: I bought this for my husband for Christmas, as I have the larger one, love it and have never had any issues with it. However we are on the 3rd Fire HD 7 now. Had to return the original one because it wasn't powering up properly. Then the replacement would not stay connected to the internet. It kept going off line after a few minutes, then back and forth. They replaced it again, and we had the same problem with the 3rd one last night. We'll see how it works tonight. Technical assistance gave every bit of their effort on the first two but to no avail. We'll see how it goes with #3 After the 2nd one went bad I asked if I could trade it in for the larger one and pay the difference, but they said they would only give me 80% of what I paid because we went past January 31st....not fair, as the process took this long and it's not our fault we received defective units.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Second one, and I still like it
review_body: I got this Fire after my wife received and used a smaller fire for several months, so there were no surprises. This is excellent for what I wanted--an easy way to read e-books and magazines. The apps for the Amazon version of the Android system are adequate for my needs, but not as rich as those from Google's site. This does not affect me, but it could be a problem for some, depending on your wishes. It also excels at watching videos of lectures on YouTube, although I have not tried many other sites. One small problem is that Flash is not available for the device, which can affect some sites that have animated content. If this is important, you might consider a Windows tablet instead. however, for what I wanted, an eBook reader, this is not surpassed by any other platform I've tried, which includes several with the appropriate app installed. It is more than adequate for most other tablet functions as well. Since this is the second one I bought, I obviously recommend the device!

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Also managing Kindle freetime content is not as easy as they claim and finding a way to list ...
review_body: Beware: the fireOS takes up about half the 8GB of storage, leaving little room for anything else. Also managing Kindle freetime content is not as easy as they claim and finding a way to list which apps take up the most storage is not a simple task (I recommend ES File Manager http://www.amazon.com/ES-Mobile-File-Explorer/dp/B008K6HN8I/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1425793469&sr=8-1&keywords=ES+file+manager [NOTE: you will have to install this as the parent account, then add it to the child account's app list, then run it as the child account, then you will NEED TO REMOVE it from the child's app list (or they will be able to do accidental damage to the OS)] I bought this to run the new Skkylanders on, it runs, but the game fills up the available storage too quickly and I'm pretty sure the bluetooth shuts off (overheats?) and causes the portal to become unresponsive (but when you go to the bluetooth menu in settings it "closes" the app that is running so you lose all your progress). I am a Kindle fan, my wife still has the first-get Fire and loves it, I just wish this Kindle was as "robust" as our older model.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Save your money and look into something like an iPad.
review_body: I returned this one because it was constantly  shutting off and rebooting.  They sent me one that I think was  refurbished/used.  It was sent in a totally different box, without the USB adapter and even the description card was missing. The first one was in the Kindle Fire box with all the accessories.  The second Kindle Fire itself was wrapped on a piece of cardboard with plastic wrap.  When I looked at the order on Amazon this one had an -R after the description, the first one didn't.  I ended up returning that one too, because it did the same thing.  Asked for a refund.  They deducted all these costs...restocking etc.  I only received a $104 refund.  Will not buy another Kindle.  *The customer service during first conversations were excellent.

review_body: The product? Perfect. Does everything I thought it would and then some. The seller? Horrible. I will never order anything from amazons warehouse again. It took a ridiculous amount of time to ship, they wouldn't take my payment for days and then sent me a message saying my payment method was declined when it actually went through. I emailed customer service about it and never got a reply. I emailed them about the shipping, still no reply. You'd think a huge company like Amazon could at least reply to their customers and do something about the problem. Again, the product is great, definitely worthy of 5 stars. But the seller is horrible and I urge anyone getting a Kindle to get it elsewhere

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: Purchase a cheaper android 7" tablet and it lasted about 6 months before something went wrong with the screen and it was difficult from the start to set up and operate....BUT this one was a piece of cake and the color is yummy too (it's a girl thing!). It is so easy to operate and I'm amazed at how long it holds a charge (so far watched several movies, read a book, searched the web, and played a couple games and it is still on it's first charge!) Now, I not sure if my turning the power off (both the added keyboard & the tablet) makes a difference, but that is what I am doing right now while it is not in use. Amazon service was amazingly quick and I'm on the trial of Amazon Prime and so far I am convinced to continue with it as the movie quality and music is fairly choice! All this is coming to you from a 70 yr old, not too technical or computer literate female...so for someone younger and hipper it will probably be almost too easy to operate! HA!

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Excellent display but too much memory taken up before even adding any content
review_body: I purchased two of these and Amazon Free Time for my children for Christmas.  Now I know we need much more memory than 8 GB.  At the time, Amazon was out of the tablets with more memory.  Well, by the time the tablets were subdivided into 3 profiles, it took up ALL of the memory.  I'm not exaggerating.  We could not add a single app, song, NOTHING.  Plus, the interface was not very intuitive to manage the accounts.  I had to completely factory reset this, get rid of Free time and only have one profile on these in order to allow my kids to download any apps or content at all.  We are definitely an Amazon loyal family.  I've been a prime member for 10-15 years.  I have Fire tablets, Fire TV, Fire Sticks, Kindles, etc., but I was a little disappointed with this purchase.  On the plus side, the HD display is gorgeous and the price was awesome!

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Satisfied with our upgrade from Kindle Fire G1
review_body:
Overall this is a great upgrade from the Kindle Fire G1 that my wife and I were previously using.

We have been using the new G4 version for about a week and the performance is much improved over the original G1. The interface has had some pretty substantial features added to it (better management of app shortcuts, ability to create groups, support for new features and apps, etc.), but still will still be familiar to someone accustomed to the original one.

Inclusion of the rear camera and a few new apps is particularly nice. Especially the new default install of a maps application. Although the unit does not have a GPS and cannot be use for routing, the lack of an out-of-the-box map application on the original Fire was a feature I felt was missing. Although the included app does not compare with Maps from the Google Play store, its nice to have basic location-based stuff (food, stores, addresses, etc.)

This unit is much lighter than the original. In a way, this is a double edged sword though. While the reduction in weight is nice, the unit does not feel as solid as the first generation. This and the overall low quality of the rear facing camera are probably the main reasons for the 4/5.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Adequate but not great. Unfortunately, I went back to other devices.
review_body:
I wanted to try a dedicated Fire tablet again, to replace my iPad mini for reading and light gaming. I still have two old Fires in storage and I absolutely loved those, I just needed to move on. I don't have any truly serious complaints about the new Kindle HD 7. It's just that it didn't grow on me like other models did. There really isn't anything great about the current model. The screen colors are washed out compared to my other devices and the design is bland. I also had a problem with the page number feature. When tapping the lower left corner to get the page number or progress, it often wouldn't register at all. I had to keep backing out of the book then tap the bottom left corner again, then it would register. Until making a note or highlight, then it wouldn't register again. That was very annoying since I rely on this feature.

Other than that, the sound was decent. And I could use it as a Kindle e-Reader and audiobook device. I don't mind the ads and limited app store. I knew what I was getting into. I just didn't love it, it's so lackluster. I went back to the Kindle apps on the iPad mini and Nexus 7. And I sometimes use the Kindle Voyage(Voyage is A+ so far).

I have a feeling the HDX would serve my needs and wants better. But I'm just going to keep what other devices I have and wait for the 2015 releases.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body:
I recently got this Kindle HD to replace the original Kindle Fire I got about 3 years ago. My original was working but was getting glitchy, so I decided it was time for a new one. The new Fire HDs are nice and work more smoothly, but are still similar enough to the original that you don't have to relearn everything. Granted, I usually use mine only for reading and occasionally browsing the web, but I do like the camera feature as well. One thing I like is that it provides books that are relavent to the one you are reading. It also makes quick work of posting a review of a finished book on Goodreads, and makes Goodreads more accessible. The only down side so far is the battery life drains faster than on the older kindles, but I imagine it's because the Fire HDs are a little more high-tech.
PS- i do think it's bogus that you have to pay $15 to avoid ads on the lock screen. I paid the money because I knew I'd get annoyed if I didnt, but I think that's silly.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: this is a great product. I answers most of my objections to ...
review_body:
Overall, this is a great product. I answers most of my objections to the first version of the Kindle, and has some features I never thought of. Much better migration from book samples to full versions - automatically starting you where the sample left off. Much better local/cloud control. Would like, however, to organize books in folders (history, other non-fiction, mystery, etc.) which I could do before. Help is hard to find for apps like mail or the browser (how do I "delete all" in my mail box?). Controls for book formats much better and easy to access and use. The touch screen is a little too sensitive for me - would like to control the touch, but can't seem to.

Overall a great improvement, and a great tablet - especially for the price.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Generally is what I expected it to be.
review_body: Generally is what I expected it to be. However, there are some features that I miss from my old Kindle 3 keyboard. First while the dictionary is efficient at looking up words that "push" on in the text, you can't look up words in the dictionary itself very well--at least I don't know how to do it. Secondly, when making notes in the text, there are fewer symbols available. For example, I wanted to use an ampersand, but one was not available. If I want to highlight some text, then sometimes if the dictionary comes up and blocks the text I want to highlight. I also think there were some apps available for the older Kindle that were better than what's available for the Fire. For example, I can't find a calendar app that is just for the device and has more than just very basic features. As a reader, I wish that Amazon hadn't done away with the keyboard version. I know that swiping is new and cool, but sometimes the old fashioned way was better.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body:
Amazon Kindle Fire, the first generation, set the bar high. All subsequent iterations are inferior, in my opinion.
Why? The first generation was built like a Mack Truck , very sturdy, with heft. Almost bullet proof. The newer versions have more bells and whistles, but they are cheap - and you can feel the difference. That's too bad.
For a few bucks, and if you don't mind the built in advertisements (first gen didn't have those either ) it'll do the job, but I'd counsel to spend a few more bucks and get something of better quality.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: This is my 3rd Kindle in three years. I find that they all last just about a year. When they stop charging I get a new one which I don't really mind because the price for what you get is quite reasonable. My current one, however, is two weeks old. The emails come in a day or two late or not at all, I have to sign in every time I turn it on even if I never leave the house and half the time emails aren't sent when it says that they are. I have set it so all photos that arrive as attachments are "saved" so far none have saved. It's nice to have a camera but the quality is awful, very grainy even when set on HD.  It's rather frustrating that with each new model the quality goes down as does their shelf life. I don't know if I got a lemon or if these are just reconstructed old ones. I haven't decided whether or not I'll keep it yet, already I find myself just going over the desktop. Overall, I'm pretty disappointed. I think I might just give it up and bite the bullet and get an iPad.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: BEWARE! Don't be quick to believe the full star reviews as they most likely are paid to provide those ratings.  This makes the FOURTH time Amazon has shipped us a replacement Kindle. There is a KNOWN issue with this model when the battery gets below ~30%, it will randomly shutoff without any alert or notification. Amazon refuses to acknowledge this is a major flaw with this product, therefore they keep trying to sweep it under the carpet by keep sending you NEW Kindles. Each one of them has the same issue..and it doesn't happen right away, but over time..it might be more of a hardware issue.  When watching Netflix, it seems to have a larger affect, most likely it overheats and shuts down automatically..but that's not for me to assume. It's absolutely consistent. Another small issue is that the volume will drop down nearly 50% when receiving notifications while watching Netflix..and will stay that way without returning to normal. You have to exit and re-enter Netflix. It's an incredible pain!  So I suggest you do research before buying, it's incredibly frustrating but moreso because Amazon refuses to recall the devices that are clearly unable to support high processing software, like Netflix, with their hardware.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: How many Cats have to die?
review_body: ** I edit review cause now I have proper HDMI cable. I watch prime movies now and it works well so I give 4 stars.  I like my recently purchased Kindle fire. One thing I haven?? been able to figure out is the correct micro usb to HDMI cable to link with my tv. Every cable I purchase seems incorrect. The only function i have for these incorrect cables are as nooses for roaming neighborhood cats. One by one, each cable suspends a frozen cat, linked by a cheap cable to the tree of the non-transparent Kindle Fire. How many more cats will succumb to Kindle of confusion? How many I ask you.  Kindle HD 7 purchased in Feb 2015

review_body: All the function of bigger name tablets at a fraction of the cost. Light weight, easy to navigate, and wonderful for kids with FreeTime by Amazon. We bought one for our son as FreeTime allows us peace of mind that he's playing age appropriate content without the chance to get onto the Internet or anything inappropriate. Has been durable so far and delivery with Prime was prompt with no complaints!

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Very happy with my Fire HD 7
review_body:
I've been very happy with my Fire HD 7. It has performed as I expected, with no problems so far. The weight is just right for reading and holding to watch movies and videos. I've used it to play Prime music and the sound quality has been good. I have added Prime music lists to my library and the selection has been fantastic.

I use it mostly to read Kindle books but have watched one movie. The quality of the movie was excellent and I like the X-ray feature that provides backstory and information about the scenes. All-in-all I highly recommend the Fire HD 7. I've downloaded enough free apps to not have to buy any so far. I did pay for Prime but that has been worth it.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: It's really too bad, because the kids time options from amazon and ...
review_body:
Bought this for the kids for Xmas. luckily i took it out to set it up prior to them opening. Disney Jr was not compatible, and therefore would not load. I'm sure that was probably Disney's issue with their app; but the tablet was returned for a ipad mini. It's really too bad, because the kids time options from amazon and parental control locks are much more intuitive than Apple's, and i wanted to make this work as the price point is great as well as the color options are excellent for the kids.

So we are still an exclusive Apple house (ugh). You can lock down an ipad, it's just harder and you need to select each option individually.

What good is the tablet if the #1 app the kids use is not compatible with the latest tablet version? The problem may have been solved since, but we already own the mini. it's hard to give this a poor rating, because it could have been great. It's also hard to give this a great rating, because something as basic as Disney JR should work out of the box without issue since you promote the "kid friendly-ness" of these - and Amazon should be all over the top companies to make sure apps are compatible etc. Ultimately "Santa" couldn't bring something that "doesn't work" in the eyes of the kids. Couldn't risk an Xmas Fail!

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: I originally picked up a Kindle Paper White and enjoyed that very much. This Fire 7 came as part of a Black Friday / Cyber Monday bundle. The combination of this and the other item was less than normal price of the other item (which I was going to purchase anyway). How could I refuse? It took a while to get used to it, mostly setting different fonts to find the one my eyes liked best and the right word size. With that completed I found myself reaching for this one more, until it became the first grab every time. Among other things, the color screen is a great help for identifying rocks, and plants in gardening books. The screen display gives noticeably sharper images than the paper white. I have not watched movies or played games on this, but it really works well for reading. It is a bit heavier than the paper white, but I got used to that in a short period of time.  It is definitely a keeper.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: HD 7" has a beautiful color display, sound, camera and lots of other features.  Coupled with an inexpensive Bluetooth keyboard it's much more portable than any laptop or notebook computer for occasional use--which is about all that I do. I read a lot, and while I can read e-books on the HD7", the Paperwhite is much lighter and easier to hold, handle and manipulate while reading in bed or in a chair. So, I'm glad that I have both, because each of them has very neat features not found on the other.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: Here's what I love:  quality feel, quality look and the HD on videos is amazing!  I also love how easy it is to watch Prime videos via Amazon including the pop ups with character names/actor names along with song names.  Even trivia items pop up!  If I would have known how much I would love watching movies/shows on this device I would have purchased a larger screen size.  What I don't love:  I can't add Instagram or CBS News as apps.  I don't know what other apps I can't add yet - these are the two so far I have found are not in the app store.  I have yet to take a picture with it that I like.  But I didn't buy this for the camera.  Also, it seems to take HOURS to charge.  My phone charges in an hour but this tablet needs about 5-6 hours when I run it down to a low battery.  I debated on returning it and purchasing an Android tablet because of the Instagram issue but after getting over my learning curve and enjoying the high quality of videos, I decided to keep it.  Like I wrote above, now I wish I would have ordered a larger screen.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Not too happy about the Fire HD 7
review_body: I had bought Fire HD 7 for a gift for my mother , it worked fine for 3 weeks and then the screen started to shrink until about a inch tall . So she calls Customer service, which was great . sent her out a brand new Fire HD 7, it failed to load all her content, it was stuck at 2 mins  left for download for 8 hours and then battery died . Then we tried again and it wouldn't even download anything . Called Customer service again, the were great again ! sent out 3rd replacement. This one downloaded everything fine, just waiting to see how this one lasts. Just disappointed on this product all she has on this is a few books and she watches a few movies on Prime .

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: Bought this for working trip to Australia.  Wide range of functions for very reasonable price.  You can spend more for a higher-def display, but at this size I can't really see the difference.  Video playback is also crisp.  Huge range of functions, both built in and downloadable Android apps; haven't had any of the latter fail despite what I understand to be enhancement Amazon made to the OS.  The size is the most persuasive feature--fits in coat pocket (not in jeans, however), and I was able to shlep it and the keyboard all over Australia without difficulty (the keyboard, which I got separately, is adequate for email, and possibly for more extended work once you get used to the placement of things like semicolons, which are not where your fingers expect them to be; it's a significantly bigger form factor than the Fire itself, but thin and lightweight.  Spending more for the 16 GB made sense for me--I was able to download 4 feature films for those long air flights and still have plenty of room for music, books, etc.  One odd note considering the Fire's heritage--I still prefer my paperwhite for plain old reading.  But I don't think anyone will be dissatisfied with the Fire on that count either.  So it's basically a home run.

review_headline: I loved my first Kindle Fire
review_body: I loved my first Kindle Fire. When this went on sale this year, I immediately wanted one. I ordered one shortly after it went on sale before I went on vacation. When I got it, the back panel was loose and felt very, flimsy and very cheap. I called Amazon and the customer service rep was great and sent me another. They even shipped it overnight so I would have it in time for my vacation. Unfortunately, the second one had the exact same issue. The back panel is cheap, thin and flimsy. It feels like a thin piece of cardboard. I sold the second one to a co-worker and went to Best Buy to get the HDX version, which I am very happy with. I would not recommend this version.

review_body: I really like this tablet. Great value and quality for the price. I got it to get ebooks from our local library, but we ended up using it for a lot more than just that. However, I do enjoy the fact that my library card is connected to my Amazon account and I can borrow books for my Kindle through my account using wi-fi. This tablet lets you download apps and setup parental controls and allow kids to play for a particular amount of time (as a reward and such). Of course, it's not the best tablet out there, but the quality of it amazes me (in comparison with other tablets for the same price). I would definitely recommend this tablet to anybody who is looking for an inexpensive device for a child or to take on a plane or a trip.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Find a better, less restrictive option
review_body:
Honestly, this device is too restrictive. Most videos won't play because there's no real way to get the plugins to play them without going out of your way to instal an old Fire browser called Dolphin which then gives you the fun of every single website you visit from that point on asking which browser you want to open it in, even though you set your default browser to Dolphin. The app store is pretty limited, most useful apps are not available, but you have your choice of games if that's what you like.

Restrictions aside, the device doesn't hold up over time. Recently my device has started to shut itself off every time I connect to wifi unless my device is plugged into a wall, which defeats the "mobile device" purpose. I was lucky to finish a college course because I had rented a digital textbook from Amazon (also not recommended) when my device started acting up and it took me awhile to figure out that I could run it as long as I was plugged in. Being barely at the year mark for owning it didn't help and my only option from Amazon was to purchase a discounted refurbished device, like I'd trust another tablet from them after my current experience. I'm not putting another penny towards an Amazon Tablet.

Frankly, I won't be buying another amazon tablet. I love my Paperwhite but have more hate towards Kindle Fire than is probably rational at this point. I've never felt so much dislike or disappointment from a device from Amazon and I will not be trusting another tablet in the future.

I now have a very shiny, no surface damage, still charges device that I can't take anywhere or do anything with because the wifi doesn't let me keep the device ON which is kind of the point of using a tablet: wifi and function.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: You will want to buy a decent Android tablet
review_body:
Got 2 on 2014, Black Friday, so I've been using it for a while.

The overall experience is simply frustrating. Ok, I know this is a cheap tablet, but there are some details that made me think "Why didn't I buy a decent Android tablet? It was not worth saving a few bucks" :
- I don't have access to the play store, so MANY apps are simply not avaiable, and will never be
- It takes pictures, but they are terrible,
- Many little bugs (opening URL links from apps sometimes does not work, embeded youtube videos don't go fullscreen, and the list goes on.. you'll find them all over the system). FireOS is new compared to iOS and Android and has lots of bugs.
- Battery life sucks

So, unless you are deeply inside the Amazon ecosystem, there's no reason to buy this tablet.
And even if you are, write down the pros and cons... Buying this tablet will not be the only way for you to use Amazon services.

I have been stuck on the couch for two weeks due to foot surgery and Kindle has made it bearable. Great screen. Responds to first touch. review_headline: Amazon's Kindles have almost completely retired 3 HUGE, unsightly desktop computers in the house.
review_body: I got envious watching wifey relax in bed and do almost everything I had to sit in front of a desk top computer to do, so I bought this as a gift and I took over her older model. I didn't need a camera but she loves having one and uses it all the time for stills and video. I think it will be nice some day to have all the family memories she is creating. I got the 16 gig one because I knew she would want to store lots of pictures and videos. Kindles are also great for kicking back in bed or in your favorite chair and reading or surfing the web. Now we both often read ourselves to sleep at night with our Kindles. I got the older Kindle in the deal but it works fine for what I want to do and it came with lots of hugs and kisses!  The bigger model would have been nice, but I just couldn't justify the extra cost at this time. I hope the 8.9's do get more affordable one day though as our eyes aren't getting any younger.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Not worth the "hassle free" box it came in.
review_body:
Don't get unless you expect very little from a tablet. Regrettable purchase. Before I sent it back I kept it for about two, three weeks, to see if there were any redeeming features, and by the time I was done, I wanted to use the Kindle Fire as actual kindling for a campfire.

It was well below expectations as a full-fledged "tablet". For one, no versions of the device allow you to add a wallpaper. But if you don't pay more, Amazon programs the device to display random ads on your lockscreen and homescreen. But in neither case can users add their own pictures??? K. The whole built-in-ads thing kinda works as a cost cutter for apps and websites, but if users choose between two *physically existent* devices and can't afford the artificially more expensive one, how's it make sense to put in ads to buy more stuff?

Also: Setting up the pre-installed mail app is impossible to figure out. Watching video in browser is interrupted by stupid address bar and tabs at the top -- even in fullscreen. It's an android device with zero customizability, and no access to the Google play store. Support for Google Apps is basically nonexistent -- humongous problem since I use them all for school: Google Drive/docs/sheets, gmail, calendar, everything.

I was hoping to use it at least as an eBook reader for schoolbooks I bought digitally. Still failed. If you count the fact that there were words on the screen and I can read, I guess its kind of okay. It's cool that this one small device can hold thousands of books, but then again, I never really wanted to carry around thousands of books at once anyway. I would rather endure carrying around the three or four books I'm reading at the time and putting the rest on a shelf that than spend over a hundred dollars for an ability I already have. Without a second thought, I long ago would only have bought paper books if I knew what I was getting into with Amazon. They have ruined my experience with them completely, and I would actively discourage friends and relatives from using their digital products.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Great Device at a Reasonable Price
review_body: The Kindle Fire HD 7 exceeds my expectations.  I can read e-books, watch movies, watch some television shows, make and receive free phone calls, send and receive free text messages, send and receive e-mails, perform internet searches, and much more.  The 7 inch display also seems to be the perfect size - not too large and not too small.  If I was forced to make any kind of criticism of this device, I would point out some of the icons and menu option layouts could be organized in a more logical manner.  There is an unnecessary learning curve involved in moving from screen to screen and icon to icon - sometimes a screen will come up and it isn't clear what kind of tapping or swiping is needed to get off that screen.  It would make more sense if the 'back' arrow and 'forward' arrow were ALWAYS visible on EVERY screen.  But this is a relatively minor complaint.  I have been VERY happy with this Kindle HD 7 purchase !

review_headline: This Kindle Fire HD 7 is an excellent purchase for a child as well as an adult.
review_body:
My new Fire HD 7, works great. The colors are bright, beautiful and sharp. I use it everyday to watch videos and read books and programs. I also bought one for my 13 year old grandson last fall and he loves his too.
The construction of these Kindles is very sturdy and solid. I have a new laptop and 2 other tablets, but I prefer using my Kindle Fire so I only use the others occasionly.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Good, but put off by modified android and infinite ads
review_body: I really like this thing. I wish it would just run stock android, and I am pretty put off by the advertisement that pops up every time I wake it up. I bought the product and it indefinitely uses it to advertise crap to me, that really sucks. Thinking about rooting it because of that. It is pretty good as a reader and browser, haven't tried watching videos on it but I assume the formats it might support are pretty limited. Probably at least good for youtube, although haven't really even tested that. It does run Hearthstone nearly flawlessly (a bit slow in menu screens only), which is what I usually use it for. Great to have this thing when watching something that doesn't require full attention with the girlfriend.

Frustrating.  Wish they had kept it the old way.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: I'm looking forward to learning all the functions.
review_body:
I'm still learning all about my new Fire HD 7. I'm glad there are directions and on-line tutorials. I mainly bought it to play audio books on as I am visually impaired. Amazon offers many audio books for minimal prices, if not free. My only problem is navigating the Fire. If the instructions on the Fire are there, I find them too small for me to follow. I use a magnifier. I'm hoping to find out that there are a couple of buttons I can push to create larger print of instructions and buttons on the Fire. The books can be enlarged beautifully. I'm a little in trouble because my computer is asking for a disk to support the Fire, and I did not receive one, and the alternate method is not available. But, not being the most techy person in the world , I may just be missing something. It is thrilling to have so many books available instantaneously!! And a wonderful selection. So many c
Classics were offered for Free.

review_headline: Yeah, mine quit working in two months.
review_body:
This is for the Magenta 16GB one, but they don't have it listed.
Ya know, I was so excited to receive this as a gift for Christmas. My previous Kindle had gotten stolen, and this was my unfortunate replacement. Low and behold, the brand new Kindle I received broke in two months. Just wouldn't turn on, or do anything. It was working one moment, then stopped. So, called customer care, and tried trouble shooting. They said that they would be sending a NEW one in the mail. Yeah, I got a refurbished one. It's really funny to know that they are going to send me a previously broken Kindle in the mail when the Kindle that I have had for TWO MONTHS, in a protective case, broke. That refurbished Kindle shut off on me during set up while it still had 75% battery life. How unfortunate that I might just resort to not using a Kindle anymore.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: I've only had my Kindle fire for about 3 weeks but so far I love it. I mostly use it for reading and checking social media (twitter and Facebook). As far as speed is concerned I'd say it's fast enough. Definitely not blazing but like I said no real complaints there. When I was looking to buy one I saw other reviews where lots of people doted on the amazing sound of the Kindle fire. Although this wasn't a priority for me I must say that the sound has blown me away as well. It has kicked me out of apps a few times but not so much to make me regret my purchase. I got the Kindle fire because I was using my Samsung Galaxy S4 so much that I'd have to charge it two or 3 times today. My Kindle has remedied that situation as I only charge my phone overnight now and the Kindle gets charged every 2 or 3 days with what I would call moderate use. As long as nothing unforeseen happens I would definitely buy another one in the future

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Love, love, LOVE my Kindle Fire!
review_body:
Absolutely LOVE my new Kindle Fire! I had never used one before and bought one for my myself with Christmas money during a Cyber Monday deal on Amazon. Great looking, lightweight, easy to use. I have already read 16 novels in my first 12 weeks of having it so it has definitely helped me step up my reading.

Note that most libraries have "Overdrive" accounts where you can download e-books for free. There's also sites like Project Guttenberg with tons of older books for free as well. I had tried the "Kindle Unlimited" on here for a month but found is ironically quite LIMITED on the selection of books. My library has all the current books I want to read not just obscure titles like "Kindle Unlimited".

I also love the pink and keep mine in a pink leather case I found at Staples. Note that there's several generations of Kindles and not all sellers of cases on here are clear which Kindles theirs fit. I returned one that didn't fit mine and was REALLY cheap looking and the M-Edge one I found at Staples is a nice hot pink leather with black suede inside and fits perfectly, feels great in my hands. In my opinion far better to buy the case in person or at least see the case you want in person THEN buy it on here if Amazon sells it for a better price.

review_body: I purchased this for my mother as a Christmas present.  I gave her my old iPad a few year ago and it gave out on her and she was so disappointed.  I could not afford another iPad so I read the reviews and decided to go with the kindle. (plus it was on sale) Well she loves it.  She tells me almost everyday how happy she is with it.  She takes it to Church, Bible study and everywhere else she goes.  Most places have wifi so she's able to check her emails and she loves playing hangman and word search.  My mother is 75 years old and is a wiz on this device.  The best part is how light weight it is.  To be honest, after seeing hers I really want one for myself!!  This is a great device and has come long way from the first addition which I purchased for myself a couple of years ago and that one was good.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body:
I love the Kindle Tablets. I love to read and my kids desperately needs to work on their reading, so I got them kindles. 1st generation kindle fire with the LCD screen is good but now is out dated due to technology updates and incompatible apps so I upgraded to the Kindle Fire HD 2012. Love this Kindle. Still love it! Love it so much I decided to get the new Kindle Fire HD 7 inch for only $114.00! On sale. Beautiful device, and it comes in pretty colors! But, I was really disappointed when I looked at the app selection! It was very limited. The 2012 Kindle Fire HD had more selection. For a new tablet, I expected better. Upside! I went online and looked at a way to get good apps for my new Kindle. First go to your settings and allow installation of outside apps. Download the ES file from Amazon App Store. Then go on line and download 1 moble market app. ( look on line on how to do this. The man who posted this information explains it way better than me ) because of 1 moble market and that man who posted that information, it saved me from returning my new Kindle back to Amazon!
1 moble market has way better apps for the new Kindles than the Amazon App Store. Because of all the research I had to do to better my experience with this new Kindle, I gave it a 4 star rating. I would of gave it a 1, but that man (what ever his name) changed that!!!

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Works Well ... Needs More Customization on the Device
review_body:
I'd give this a 5 star but I really don't like the fact that on this android OS you can't run the google play store with the expansion of apps. A couple of the games I play on my phone I can't transfer over to this device for that reason. The second reason I take away a star is that there does not appear to be any way to customize the background/screensaver. This is 2015 ... people like to play around with that sort of stuff. You can get this Fire in 5 different exterior colors, but you can't change anything on the inside? Kind of lame Amazon ... just saying ... Otherwise, everything else is as expected. The display is gorgeous and the apps that you can get on it all work flawlessly. I guess I missed some of my extra research ... didn't realize they closed all the rooting loopholes (for now) on the latest models.

I definitely suggest getting the screen protectors and a nice case. I picked up a case for less than $12 that fits it well and gives you all the neat features of the expensive amazon cases (lift the cover, wakes it up, stylus pen comes with, leather, color of your choice, etc ...) The screen attracts finger prints just like the screen on most any phone does without the screen protectors.

Would probably give this a 3.5/5 star but no 1/2 star rating available lol

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: kindle fire hd 7 after a couple days use
review_body:
It's made very well. Sturdy and feels like it will last and not break in 2 weeks. I can watch Netflix with no glitches or buffering. It goes right to my wifi after initial set up with no problems. It arrived quickly and was packaged well. I had the 1st generation Kindle for several years and even dropped it while sleeping and stepped on it when waking up without breaking it. This seems to have the same quality construction. My first book order came through quickly. What I needed was quickly being able to order from the Amazon site, get books, watch Netflix and fluff around on Facebook and read email. That's really all I need. The camera turn out to be quite nice. I was pleasantly surprised since I use a dslr for my camera needs. A quick shot from the device isn't bad at all. Video is crisp and clear, sound is wonderful through my ear phones and without. The price for the quality you get is top notch and it works wonderfully every time it's turned on. All in all what the heck else could you ask for? Except............

My question now is.........what the heck happened to the battery life? I used to be able to charge my 1st generation kindle once a week. This is more like a phone battery. Yes, it last longer than a phone but I have to charge every single day now.

Ads? You really need to give me ads? My opening screen has an ad on it? You give me "suggestions" that I didn't ask for? My son is 29 years old, what in the world do you think I need with a bottle nipple ad? At least let these ads pertain to my shopping over the years.

Kindle (phone) support went down. Sorry boys and girls but outsourced support is always a bad idea. I can't understand them, they can not understand me and the connection is never good. Considering all other Amazon support is the best I've ever experienced and why I am such a loyal Amazon supporter, this is sad indeed.

Please please I can not stress enough, Amazon please do not go the route everyone else goes. You have a great product, you have what we want with better quality than would be expected at the price you give. Some of us are serious readers and would stand on a box and scream your support to all those other tablets out there. Don't turn this into a venture. We are loyal customers here to the very end. Don't go down that road and ad us to death. Don't take away from the greatest product at the greatest price.

I'd of given 5 stars even with the battery draining faster than the first Kindle I owned but those ads, man those ads have got to go. I'll be looking into that as soon as I finish my review.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body:
I am huge fan of almost all Amazon products, but sadly I have been very disappointed with this device. The operating system and user interface are very slow, frequently freezing up. The hand gestures to control the screen are not intuitive. The battery life is very short. The 8GB drive is easily consumed as the operating system takes up much of the space.

One of the most attractive features was the FreeTime features for kids which allow you to limit browsing time and content. However, I find FreeTime to be very confusing. It puts content about princesses and dolls in profiles for boys (and vice versa). Games, movies and books that you purchase do not necessarily show up in FreeTime without you explicitly adding them. If you reach a time limit on Free Time the device often freezes up.

However, when it works (60% of the time) it does work well.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: I love my kindle fire.  It's one of the best investments I ever made.  It works for every age group in my family, my 80+ mom, my teenage grandkids, my 9 year old grandson, and it even keeps my toddler nephew entertained when we are stuck in traffic or at doctors offices.  In addition the amount you choose to spend on books and apps is entirely up to you.  There are so many free options you really never have to buy anything however you can also spend money personalizing it to your lifestyle or wants.  I swore I would never buy apps but after using some of the free apps you find upgrades have a little extra oomph for not much money.  Also if you have to contact customer service for any reason they are the best and most informed people I've come across.  The only regret I have is not having a camera on my device and the 2 megapixel device on the lower priced kindle just doesn't cut it for me.  I really enjoy my device and highly recommend it.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: Has anyone been watching the latest TV commercials for the Kindle Fire HD, which proclaim how resilient it is to physical damage, and shows a device falling from the top of an SUV onto a driveway and supposedly survives? Its is total B.S. I was very alarmed to see this false advertising. One of our Kindle Fires was dropped from 3 feet, it was enclosed in a case and the glass screen cracked in several places. And Amazon has no replacement policy on that--I just got done discussing with a customer service rep who admitted that the TV ad shouldn't be making these claims. They should remove this TV ad immediately.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body:
The Kindle that was shipped to me does not work properly. The screen skips all over the place, and the thing seems to have a mind of its own with opening up random apps and websites. I've tried calling and chatting with Amazon, and now am attempting the email route. I'm trying to get this defective Kindle replaced, and having no luck. Honestly, I'm a bit shocked. I've never had this kind of issue with Amazon before.

Overall, I'm a huge fan of the Kindle. I own several, going back to the very first one that came out. This one was to have been a replacement for my three year old 6" Fire. So far, I'm still using my old one.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Great hardware; now, about those apps...
review_body:
Screen resolution is very good. Picture is crisp, sharp, balanced, and pleasing. Sound is very good for a unit this size. Speed is also quite acceptable.

The only thing that keeps this from a solid, no-brainer 5-star rating is the difficulty that Amazon imposes on the user to load and use any app that didn't come from the Amazon app store. After being a long-time Kindle, Blackberry phone and Blackberry tablet user (yes, they make/made a tablet), I decided to make the switch to Android. I did, and haven't looked back. I assumed (I still think reasonably so) that my Android apps used on my phone would work on my Android Fire tablet. Well, there's the rub. Some of them, more than a few, simply can't be found on the Amazon app store. And the Google Play store says their apps won't work on my device (this isn't true, but that is what it says.) Bottom line, I can still do some things on my phone I can't do on my Fire tablet, besides making calls. That isn't cool with me. There are ways to get around it, but "work arounds" found on the internet which may or may not work with varying effectiveness is a particular joy I thought I'd left behind when I left Blackberry. Not entirely.

Amazon: I get that you want us to use your app store and yours alone. You're a jealous lover and we get that. But that kind of (very) old-school fidelity doesn't work today. Sure, make your hardware work incredibly well with your content, but don't shut out other Android apps. Android hardware and apps are what make it #1 in the world. Don't mess with this.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: Here is why I am giving it only 3 stars.  There is no parts replacement support for Amazon for this.  My son dropped it once and cracked the screen.  It was totally our fault.  But now it makes sounds and you can tell it works, but the screen won't light up. I have it apart, but can't find the replacement screen for it.  I can see how to do it, but have spent hours online trying to find the part and reading other reviews to no avail.  Type in Kindle Fire HD 7 screen replacement anywhere on Amazon and the search yields no results.  Like no one else needs to replace the screen?!  This is Amazon' product.  Why don't they support it?  I can find all kinds of replacement screens on Ebay, but not 100% sure they have the right one (1st gen, 2nd gen, 3rd gen etc.).  So we have a $140 paperweight that makes the normal sounds, but you can't seen anything.

Overall: This will be my last kindle fire purchase, unless significant changes are made. It is an ok device, but a great device with a better U.I. and access to the playstore.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Typical amateur problems you'd expect on a $100 device, but I'm willing to live with it FOR NOW, because it only cost me ~ $100.
review_body:
It's shiny & cool looking, but really average (or below).

Pros:
Nice size and a convenient way to check email & browse the web.
Neat little table for only $100.

Cons:
Kindle limits you to the Amazon app store, and therefore forces you to use sub-par apps.
Only 1 video chat app allowed (Skype); the actual video being sent is smaller than the one you see!
No google maps (sad face).
Every time I try to play a trailer on Flixter, it shuts down (can't play this video; force close).
Netflix stops or forces close occasionally.
Loads of reflective glare coming off the screen.

Typical amateur problems you'd expect on a $100 device, but I'm willing to live with it FOR NOW, because it only cost me ~ $100.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body:
This is a KINDLE. It is a really wonderful Kindle with the capability to watch a video, but it is a kindle in my opinion not a tablet. This is not a tablet to be compared with any of the other leading tablets on the market. It's a great electronic device. But it is far more cumbersome to just browse the web (could just be because I am used to the iOS interface...) It is perfect for magazine subscriptions. It is far superior to other tablets in that realm. And I love it as just a kindle as well.

My use for this is that I have a large number of work-related PDF's that I need to have handy and searchable at any given time. I travel constantly for work. I was keeping these items on my other tablet. But, it was soaking up space and I didn't have space for all my work docs, pics, music, apps, etc. I had to branch out and find another, more cost effective way to manage my professional documents electronically. This is the PERFECT solution. It is wonderful for my work documents, even better than my other tablet! I keep all my documents on there and it's portable. So portable I can slide it into a pocket and head out anywhere for work with every pub/document/instruction/etc I need. And it's freed up tons of space on my web browsing tablet to have fun on that one. Sometimes I use the kindle for things that are not professionally based and it's not as wonderful, but for its price, it is not bad.

READING
-Books: backlit, syncs to your kindle, my husband complained once that it synched in the wrong spot, but we've had just that one issue. I prefer to read on just a Kindle, vice the Fire, because the backlight and screen is less harsh on my eyes.
-magazines: BEST magazine reading medium, orgnaize your subscriptions, flip through like a magazine
-documents: good for pdfs and docs that you may have, searchable and with the ability to take notes/highlight

BROWSING:
-works well for browsing, although the screen is a bit small to have it as your only item. You could not abandon the computer and just browse on this.

APPS:
-So far the apps I have looked at have been disappointing. However, I've only looked at a small number of apps.

SHOPPING:
-Shops on amazon like a dream. I do a ton of amazon shopping and this is really wonderful.
-Shops on other websites like most other tablets, doable, but not easy
-App based shopping: I have not used any shopping apps to shop on the Fire.

BATTERY:
-my biggest complaint, my battery does not last nearly as long as other tablets or kindle's.
