product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Absolutely the worst customer service I have ever experienced
review_body: Absolutely the worst customer service I have ever experienced.  I bought this and a Fire TV for my son in college.  Amazon would not allow him to use the free Prime and insisted on charging him 52 dollars.  Instead, we put a stop payment on the charge and are returning it.  We spent 4 hours being bounced around customer service agents in India and the Philippines who were completely incompetent.  When I finally spoke to an American english speaking manager, she made no attempt to rectify the situation.  Can't wait for Alibaba to come to the US and destroy Amazon.  THEY know how to treat a customer.  I'll be paying off my Amazon card and will stop using them altogether.  Unbelievably poor treatment of their customers.  Don't bite the hand that feeds you Amazon, that's why your market share is tanking.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: Love the kindle.  I just wish amazon would provide options for personalization (i.e. the screensaver and background screen).  No fun without adding your own personal touches.  And since I get these for my kids I wish I went with another device.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: It's pretty decent.  One thing though, I absolutely hate about Amazon in general is how difficult it is to sort through their shows, books, etc.  Hulu and Netflix have wonderful search tools that make it incredibly easy to find what you are looking for, or just to browse.  All seasons are in one icon, rather than 4 or 6 or however many seasons were put out there.  I have had such difficulty in two of their tablets now, finding browsing options for JUST free or Prime shows, or Prime books.  And when you check out a book you have to sign in to your account again, then go to the book, download, and then press that you want to go to that app, etc.  It is messy for no reason.  I registered the tablet, therefore it should be hooked directly to my account if I want to borrow a book, or watch a free movie with one click.  I think this is the last time I will buy an Amazon product.  I have the same issues with their Fire Stick.  Search options suck.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB

review_body: It didn't fit the screen as well as I thought it should - does the job as far as fingerprints.

review_body: Isn't compatible with anything but kindle stuff.  Doesn't mirror through chromecast nor on its own.  Something this new should be be able to be cast on smart tv's at least.  I don't like the layout because the apps aren't on the main screen except for thumbing through recently used stuff.  Almost returned it but decided to keep as backup to my nexus7 which is getting tired.  I keep it home and take this with me.  It's also kinda ,complicated to teach my 83 year old dad to use as I also bought one for him.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: I used to love my kindle but decided to finally chuck amazon's Kindle ...
review_body:
I can only give Kindles 1 star. : I used to love my kindle but decided to finally chuck amazon's Kindle products.
The Fire HD 7 was my second Kindle fire 7. Both were problematic with the Fire HD 7 being a bomb due to an Amazon update. I bought the Fire 7 HD 16gb (model H with the micro hdmi "out" located next to the power input) in late 2013. It had a few problems right from the start, (insertion of letters or numbers from opposite sides of the keyboard from where you tapped, etc.) which I reported to Amazon. Then both Amazon and Gmail did an update in February which became incompatible..ie. I could no longer delete email AND the Kindle contents could no longer be seen by my XP console. Thus, I couldn't remove downloaded docs or pix or music from the Kindle HD. Amazon blogs showed that many other owners were having similar problems. I reported to Amazon, and then followed a nightmare of hours & hours of tech phone help and 3 refurbished replacements. They told me they were sending new ones but they didn't. The problems were never solved which were caused by the update. It cost a lot of money to buy new. It only worked somewhat well for 6 months. They would not credit my HD 16gb towards purchase of a newer model (like the newer 7) where hopefully these problems didn't exist. So, although Kindles are cheaper than iPad mini, Kindles are not worth the costs cuz Amazon doesn't fully stand by their products. I don't know if the newer models work better or if they've changed their service policies. But I can only give them one star now.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: If they gave 1/2 starts I would have given this 2.5 stars.  I really do love all things Amazon, but this Kindle has been a little disappointing.  I got it to replace my 3 year old Kindle Fire (the original), which still works well, but the battery seemed to be dying faster and I was just looking for a little update.  The battery life on my 3 year old fire is equal or better compared to my new fire.  We have poor internet at our house, but my old fire works great on it, the new fire is always asking for cell wireless, and is pretty much useless because I mostly use it for streaming tv shows.  The new fire is lighter than the old fire, so that is nice.  The screen is really nice and clear, and I liked the options for colors this time around.  The sound is much better on the new Kindle, which is nice.  Overall since is needs really great internet reception and the battery dies so quickly, it sits in the corner while I use my old kindle.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: It doesn't hold a charge for very long

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: Very disappointed. Error message: Taking too long to connect. Either your password is incorrect or something is wrong with your network. After lots of wasted time online, I spoke to customer support and was told they've had a lot of issues with people being unable to connect with these; support said I need a firmware update and should call the modem manufacturer. They gave me the phone number; that's all they could do. I rent the modem from Comcast, and I guess it's too old for this device, but my Kindle keyboard e-reader connects to my wifi fine.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: When I first recieved the kindle it was awesome. After about a month it started running slow, and not functioning properly. Its not a bad for the price but it is not what I expected from the other reviews. Also when I click a link from an email it does not load properly. I always have to click the link, exit back out and go back into it. Not a game changer, but it is kind of troublesome. I would probably not reccomend this to anyone just because it does not work properly.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: So much potential, but it can't replace a fully functional tablet.
review_body: I actually like my fire tablet, it is just the right size to be portable yet large enough to be used. I had to take 2 stars away: 1 the silk browser is not the best browser so I downloaded Firefox. 2 too many of my favorite apps are on the google play store. This means I have to keep my other tablet for those apps. So I can't replace my other tablet. If you can live with the limitations this is a very good tablet. I wish I had gotten the HDX with more memory. Going to try fire tv and test out its compatibility.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: DO NOT BUY ELECTRONICS FROM THIS WEBSITE!!!!
review_body: I used to love my kindle. I received it as a Christmas gift 2 years ago.  My first one stopped charging after a few weeks and Amazon replaced without issue. I also purchased the extended 2 year warranty. Don't bother. It is not honoured. Recently my kindle stopped typing and my keyboard would disappear. I noticed last night that the back of my kindle is loose. You can touch it and it pushes in. I was told I had to purchase a new kindle as my warranty expired a month before. I purchased the extended warranty about 2 weeks after I received my kindle for Christmas. So how could it expire a whole month before I received it? It doesn't matter when the warranty was purchased. It goes back to the date of the kindle purchase. SO you do not actually get the full 2 year extended warranty you purchased. I will not purchase another kindle. I do not recommend purchasing anything that you cannot just bring into your local store.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: The stock OS is crap. You cannot customize anything, the apps from Amazon aren't half as plentiful or good as Google. Definitely will root it and use Android on it.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: I was very excited because I have had a Kindle Paper White and have LOVED it. The Fire HD has been the most ...
review_body:
My husband purchased the Kindle Fire HD for me as my only Christmas gift for this year. I was very excited because I have had a Kindle Paper White and have LOVED it. The Fire HD has been the most disappointing gift that I have ever received. Since I have been using the Kindle Paper White for years I felt that stepping up to the Fire HD would be no problem. Whenever you choose a certain area such as to email, etc., the Fire HD will turn off without any provocation. You are never on any setting for more than a few seconds before it shuts off and goes back to the log in page of Amazon Fire. It will then come back on without being prompted. Because of this you cannot use any setting AT ALL.
I will never purchase a new product of yours that has been introduced without it being on the market for awhile until it is proven. I am totally upset with Amazon for not doing its best to make sure that its products are tested so that its customers are protected from this kind of thing. We are concerned that our Fire HD could be a refurbished unit because of the numerous problems. I am not able to use ANY area of the Fire HD. My husband is going to purchase an Ipod Mini to replace this for me. I hope that you will in the future live up to the name of an Amazon product again, otherwise I feel sure that your sales will drop off dramatically.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: We bought 3 Kindle Fires for our kids for Christmas.  I am beyond disappointed that the only way to set time limits Is if you're using the Amazon free time app. Kids older than 8, which is the top age free time is geared towards, (even some adults) need time limits on these devices too. I'd encourage Amazon to rethink this and include a time limit feature on all their devices. The kids are loving them though...

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: I wouldn't know I cancelled my order due to change of delivery twice and still couldn't get product before Christmas.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: Amazon did not deliver my Fire HD as promised. I placed the order on Dec 1st. on Dec 16th, when it still had not arrived, I contacted amazon to follow up on the shipping. Web-site stated it would not arrive until Dec 24th. I then paid 14$ to change shipping to the 2 day rate. I was promised that my Fire would arrive by 8pm on Dec.18. On Dec 18th I received an email stating that my Fire now would not arrive until Dec 30th. The most annoying part of this story is everyday I would receive an email from amazon about a different sale they had that day on Kindle and Kindle Fire. SO I called Amazon and spoke to a call center where it was very hard to understand what the person was saying. She said the soonest I would receive the fire was the 24th. Remember, I ordered this Dec.1st and there was no mention of a back order. I cancelled my order and went to best buy and bought the Fire. So much for the Amazon promise.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: The memory is much too small.  The preloaded programs take up over half the 8GB memory.  I installed free time for my children only to find there wasn't enough space to load any books or apps into it let alone watch any movies on it. Returning it tomorrow.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: While it serves my needs, I'm quite disappointed with my Fire.  After seeing my friend's iPod, I decided to try the Kindle Fire because of price.  I have had had a Kindle Reader for several years and loved it.  Although I do enjoy reading books on the Kindle Fire, I find that the battery life is no where near the 8 hours they say it has.  More like 4 or maybe 5.  The worse thing about it is I must reboot it daily and sometimes more than once a day due to it freezing or at best slowing down.  I get kicked off the web for no reason as sometimes it just blacks out.  I've returned 3 previous Fires thinking it was a defect in the ones I bought.  The first was a factory refurbish and the second was new which I had the same problem with.  I returned that for a better model and still have the same problem.  In conclusion, for the money, it's a good product.  Sometimes it's frustrating when it locks, but when I reboot it, it works perfectly.  I play some card games and Mah Jong (which I'm addicted to) and it works fine for a while. I've spoken with Customer Service and they're very helpful and sympathetic but can't seem to solve the problem.  So I'm resigned to the fact it's a fault with the product.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: Kindle does not allow you to access the web from a child's profile. The parental controls were why we purchased the Kindle for our kid. However, had we known he would have no web access we would not have purchased. Very dissapointing. We were excited to get him a tablet he could play on as well as access his school appointed homework web site. Falls well short of our expectations.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Not necessarily an upgrade if your previous Kindle Fire still works.
review_body: So far, I'm not impressed with these machines at all. I bought two for my kids for Christmas when their original Kindle Fires were starting to die. I bought them in color so they can tell them apart and that was a mistake. The color cases make the machine feel cheap in your hand. The original Kindle Fire felt solid and I miss that. On top of the cheap feel these machines are glitchy. Both of them shut down at random, and when they do that you have to hold the power button in for 30 seconds or more in order to get it turned back on. I had to do a factory reset on one of them the first day we opened it. Apps that used to work just fine are no longer stable on these machines and several of the new apps that we bought over the Christmas sale are completely worthless. I'm going to spend some time on the phone with Amazon tech support but I'm on the verge of sending these back.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: kindle is great. Amazon customer service, not so much.
review_body:
Broke four days into using it. Out of the box factory defect. But that wasn't the worst of it. Amazon sent me a replacement..... a refurbished one. Lied to me and said it was brand new. Not what I purchased. It was plain as day refurbished and incomplete with half a charger. So, I called back. Had to be reimbursed and had to rebuy one, but not the color I wanted, since in the week of dealing with them, they stopped making white. So, had to settle for black. Now, I am waiting for my Kindle to come in the mail, which wont be in my hands for another ten days.
Kindles are great, when they work. I've had the first gen for a long time, never had a real problem.
If you buy a Kindle Fire, you will enjoy it. Just be prepared if it breaks, because Amazon has the worst customer service.

In addition to downloading about 10 educational apps for my 5 year old 90% of my storage space was utilized. I guess it would have been to my advantage to purchase more than 8 GB.

While the screen size is nice and the graphics look great I spend way to much time trying to figure out which App I do not need on the device so I can download  another App. I am very sorry I did not buy the extra gigs, I had no idea that the operating system and preinstalled Apps that come on it (and can not be removed) take up so much of the available space.  I am basically not happy with my purchase.  On the upside the battery charges faster and lasts longer. Much nicer then the previous kindle fire I had.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: meh...    It feels cheap in comparison to the other Kindles that I have purchased. I had to return the first one sent because one of the corners of the screen the pixels didn't work and they were blacked out. The second works well but the battery life is very short and has to constantly be charged. I bought this one to replace my first Kindle Fire, the first model made. That was a solid machine and has been a great machine. I liked it enough that I also bought another for the wife. It was a second generation and it also works like a champ.   My first Kindle's only problem was the recharge usb port for the recharger that was weak and finally failed after many years of use. It cost more to fix then replace the Kindle for a new one so I bought this one. I also bought a cover for the new Kindle to protect it but it is very difficult to keep clean. I only give it three stars because I am comparing it to my first. I hope that this one lasts longer then my first. Fingers crossed.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: I just got this tablet 3 days ago & have experienced nothing but problems. My cloud from old kindle won't transfer full library because it says this device won't support the apps! You also can not unlock content in an app then apply it to freetime for kids. Amazon told me to let my kid play in regular unprotected mode so they could play their games. I spent over an hour with Amazon support & best answer I got is, they will forward my issues to support for review. Unless those things get fixed, quickly it's not worth the bother.

I know they added another camera which I won't use.  Bad move.  Guess they want to force you to buy a Fire stick (not a chance since I already have three Rokus I use).

review_body: I purchased this Fire HD 7 for my daughter and when the battery life didn't seem to last, they say they'd send me a new one. By when I got the "new one" in the mail, it was refurbished. So I paid full price for a brand new product and they wanted to replace the defective one with a refurbished one. When I asked them to just send me a brand new one, they said "they couldn't". So I just got a full refund. I wouldn't recommend buying this simply because they tried to pull one over on me by sending me a refurbished one without telling me, even though i paid for a brand new product. Not very good business in my opinion.

review_headline: buy a tablet and the kindle app, don't buy the kindle
review_body:
I had a kindle that lasted two years but the USB port failed. There was no way for me to ship it some where and get it fixed.
The replacement part was about ten dollars and Amazon will sell it to me but not the kind of thing I had the experience to repair and and Amazon won't help.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Great while it lasted.... Terrible Customer Service to replace the item
review_body: It was great while it lasted. I received this a gift for Christmas and it worked while the battery was on, well the battery died on the device and wouldn't charge. I plugged the charger into another device and the charger works, so it was the Kindle Fire HD 7 that was defective. I called the Amazon helpdesk to see if they could trouble shoot it or replace it. Well that was a huge mistake! The guy kept putting me on hold after every sentence and a conversation that should have lasted 10 minutes tops turned into a 25 minute conversation with multiple hold times of 2 minutes to 5 minutes. I was very disappointed in the customer service provided. All in all my only option was a replacement, which conveniently is out of stock and he told me I won't receive it until February 10th, 2015. Today is December 27th, 2014! I went online and was able to cancel my order to return the defective device and replace it myself with a quicker replacement date. My point is, if your device isn't working properly avoid contacting the amazon customer service line, because you will be very disappointed by trying to talk to someone that doesn't understand you, barely speaks english and has to read their script after every question in order to be able to answer you. Needless to say, I'm very disappointed with this experience.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Just ok as a tablet. No Google Play Store.  Freetime sucks for kids over 5-6.  I wish now that I had bought something else.
review_body:
I have mixed feelings about the Kindle Fire. First it is nice to be able to set separate profiles on it for my kids, myself, and my husband. It is fairly lightweight and seems sturdy. I bought it for my boys who are 5 and 9, so it's important for it to be sturdy. I have a few issues though. Also, since I don't think there's a way to rate Amazon Freetime, I'm going to include that here also.

Kindle issues so far:
Internet is not very fast. My Samsung Galaxy III phone has way less memory, is smaller, and is ridiculously faster than this. I expected better. It's not impossibly slow, but there's a large delay where my Galaxy has none.

Google Play Store and Kindle Fire are not compatible. There are tons (like thousands) of apps that Amazon does not have that are available on Google Play and I can't access them. That bites. It's actually nearly a dealbreaker. I don't think I'll buy another Kindle unless this is resolved. I would have done better buying a different tablet with Android. The reason I went with the Fire though is because we have Amazon Prime and Kindle Unlimited, and Freetime sounded like a good idea to keep my kids from accessing things they shouldn't. I thought Freetime would be more compatible with Prime and Unlimited.

So now here are my problems with Freetime - there are a lot. I would rate it a 1 if I could rate it:
On my profile or my husbands Kindle profile, Amazon Prime and Kindle Unlimited probably work fine (I haven't actually tried to read a book or watch a movie yet on the Fires, but I don't anticipate a problem), however, I bought these for my kids and set them up with Freetime. Amazon Prime and Kindle Unlimited do not seem to sync with Freetime very well, or in the case of Prime...at all. So lets say I wish to allow my kids to watch any PG movie on Amazon Prime. They can't do this via Freetime. This is frustrating. I want them to have access to the features I have. I just want parental controls so I can make sure they're not going to accidently access dirty movies. And I don't want to have to do it all for them. I thought this would be easier for me. It is not. They can't access Prime movies at all as far as I can tell.

Kindle Unlimited seems to have a different problem with Freetime. I can work around it, but it is annoying. What you have to do is access Kindle Unlimited via a parents/adults profile. Then get a new book. Then add it to your child's Freetime. Then they can download it to their device. This seems like a small thing right? But I have 2 kids and one of them is a 9 year old who sometimes goes through a book an hour. He's a very avid reader. I do not want to be hounded by my kids to access Unlimited every time they need a new book. Basically it is compatible, but not as compatible as I would like and the only reason I have Kindle Unlimited is because my kids are constantly asking me to download books for them.

My next problem with Freetime is that it's set up for 5 year olds. It's supposed to have 2 settings: for kids under 8 and kids 9-17. When you set up their profiles, you put in the age of your child and select which setting you want. Nearly all the same books and videos and games show up for both kids, even though my nine year old has the setting for older kids. The only difference I can really see is the background color is black for my 9 year old and blue for my 5 year old, and the suggested books and games at the top are a little different. What interest is a nine year old going to have in "But not the Hippopotamus" or "Little Critters" apps? They're not age appropriate. And the books can't be sorted by things like AR reading level, grade level, or even boy/girl. They're all mixed up in this silly thing. There's no way to sort them, and there's no way to search by reading level. They have Level 1 (learn to read books) mixed right in with chapter books. And let metell you, the chapter books are seriously lacking. There's almost nothing that my 9 year old wants to read. I don't expect them to have the most popular series books available, but I do expect way more than the current offerings. As a mom, this is a big Amazon Fail in my book. I might keep Freetime for my 5 year old, but probably not for my 9 year old. It's just not useful. I'd rather give him full access to Prime and Unlimited than limit him the way Freetime does.

So here's what Freetime needs to be for any Amazon people that might view this:

For my 5 year old, it's mostly ok, but:
I want a way to allow them to access Prime movies from my subscription that are rated G or PG, without me having to type in my code, add a movie/show, allow them access, and download the darn thing.
I want it to suggest books and move them to the top of the list based on the other books my child has shown interest in.
I want to be able to set a reading level/range for my kid, and I want those to be the only books that show.
I want it to filter out "girl" books about rainbows, unicorns, and fairytales. No offense, my boy is just not interested.

For my 9 year old, not ok:
Mostly the same as above.
I want to set a reading level/range.
I don't want baby books showing up.
I don't want "girl" books showing up for my 9 year old boy. Again, no offense. I have no problem with him reading those books, but he won't because they don't typically include farts, butts, ninjas, or vomit. He like boy books.
I want book, app, and video suggestions made based on what he's shown interest in. And I want them age appropriate. I don't want it suggesting learn to read books about trucks showing up just because he read an age appropriate chapter book about monster trucks yesterday. There's a huge difference in reading levels.
I want it to allow him access to my Kindle Unlimited, but since I also use Unlimited, I want a way to limit which books he can return to get a new book.
I do not want to have to add the Kindle Unlimited books to his profile myself. I just want him to have permission, preferably based on the preset reading level/range I mentioned above and let him go. I don't want him to download erotic romance novels, but I want him to be able to download the next 6th grade ninja book...on his own.
I want him to have access to all G and PG movies available on my Prime, and I do not want to have to authorize each one.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body:
Absolute garbage junk. I am really disappointed in amazon. There are Ad's on the tablet, that start talking when using it, if you want to turn them off you can pay amazon $15. The tablet is locked down, and rebranded with amazon, which is expected. But damn, be honest, its an android tablet, amazon rebrands the OS as FireOS, its not, its Android.

The tablet itself is cheap feeling, like they cut every corner in china to have a bottom line low end tablet. The description also said it included 1 year of amazon prime, when I turned it on, it said I only get 1 month.

There was supposed to be great parental controls and activity tracking, however, that is also something additional you must pay amazon for. The device is locked down, and locked out of google play and chrome, which was expected, but damn, give me the option.

I was expecting a stellar solid product from amazon, similar to google products. I feel like I don't actually own the device, like its something amazon is letting me borrow. Very disappointed in amazon.

review_headline: ... a Kindle Fire (used mostly for reading) and I loved it. So
review_body:
I had a Kindle Fire (used mostly for reading) and I loved it. So, when my kids received one for Christmas, I was very excited for them. That is, until, the first two apps they searched for were not available. American Girl and Disney Movies Anywhere are not available for Kindle? Are you kidding me? I had read negative reviews about the Amazon app store before, but didn't realize that it was this bad. You don't have the Disney Movies app? Really?
If you are primarily a reader, this is a great tablet. If you've looking for more, you may want to look elsewhere. I don't know why Amazon would put out such a nice device and then limit it with a sub par app store. But they have.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body:
I travel alot, and thought it will be a great idea to have a fire HD as a good QPR tablet. Big mistake. The amazon prime 'forgot' the idea of travel, so once you are off US continental, access to all content you have under the subscription is denied. 'violiation of the terms of use'. Why? once cannot take a week vacation?
Well, maybe at least in Canada? well... forget about it.

Conclusion- I am going to ask for my money back or give it to someone who travels as far as CT, just to be on the safe side.

On a scale of five stars, it gets FAIL in service and disclosure of terms and conditions. Too bad

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: New model has no HDMI jack and still does not have a memory card slot to add memory
review_body: The basic unit is OK, but calling it "HD" and not including an HDMI port (which IS on my 7" Fire HD purchased in 2012) is an outrageous downgrade by Amazon to try to extract more money from its customers to provide a jack which should be part of the HD unit.  Yes, they do sell an adapter (which just converts the USB port to an HDMI port, but doesn't even provide an HDMI cable to hook up to your TV), but they want $25 for it.  This is very disappointing.  In addition, there is no memory card slot, so you can't increase the unit's memory.  If you decide to purchase this unit, be sure to get the 16gb of memory, since the memory can't be expanded.  And they still don't provide the basic function that is in the basic Kindle of being able to set up "collections" so you can group your books.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body:
I was looking for a tablet for my daughter so she wouldnt kill my battery every time I pull it off the charger. This IS NOT a tablet. This is a digital advertisement that wants to sync with your credit card and let your child buy as much as they can click on. There is so much to complain about I will narrow down to top 3 most frustrating things with this. 1- In order to download any free or paid apps I needed to set up "one click purchasing" which means if anyone just clicked yes when asked to purchase, well then I already gave permission to charge my card. That combined with every kids app letsyou play for 3 minutes then tries to force kids into purchasing is ridiculous! 2- this device is not set up with google at all. So no gmail, and no youtube, just bing search. No youtube? What else would I be using a tablet for? (Now in fairness you can browse the internet on this with some unknown browser... but I specifically didnt want my kids going onto the internet to roam free.) 3- the lock screen background is an advertisement....? You cannot change the background at all, because that's where they putyet another scheme to get your kids to click on something without really knowing whats going on.
In closing, this doesnt do anything I wanted a tablet for. The parental controls are lacking significantly because its basically all or nothing. They offer a program called "free time" or something but I didnt even get a chance to check it out before I was putting back in the box to return.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: This tablet is a big disappointment! Memory
review_body:
This tablet is a big disappointment!
Memory: I paid for 8GB, but it came with a total of 4GB. After taking away 1GB for the operating system and you end up with 3GB of usable space.
Not good for Android apps: So far, I have only been able to load about 20% of my favorite Android apps. If you like Google apps, forget loading them.
Portability: It has to be Wi-Fi connected for most everything ??even for the help screen! It?? not a portable device if it has to be tethered to a Wi-Fi signal.
Sell, sell, sell: The device is one big commercial. You are prompted to buy something from the moment you turn it on.

In all, this thing is only good for Amazon stuff. If you??e looking for a versatile, usable table, buy something else.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Do not buy a Kindle tablet!
review_body:
We have had nothing but issues with the Kindle Fire HD 7" that we purchased! After 2 years with messing with frozen screens, sluggishness, backwards monitor, and now stripes, we are out of warranty. Amazon even sent us a replacement 9 months into ownership. The two (2) warranty apparently starts on the first Kindle. The second Kindle only gets covered for the remaining months. We had 2 lemons!

We were trying to be optimistic and bought our younger daughter a Kid's Edition Kindle. Two (2) days after Christmas, this new Kindle stopped working. Amazon is sending another replacement.

We should have learned. My 3-year old IPad has not had a single issue. Save yourself the headache! Do not buy a Kindle!!

review_body: Had high hopes for the Kindle Fire - we're a 2 Kindle family, have had a Kindle since the 1st generation and love Amazon, but the Fire is a huge disappointment. Gave to my wife for Christmas as she'd been talking about wanting one, however a few minutes after turning it on and setting it up, we realized that there is no access for Google apps, the device is slow (despite speed being a selling point), the apps randomly froze and closed, the device required rebooting several times. Not sure if being an iPhone user is one reason for the disappointment (we've never had an Android device, and Apple iOS works nearly perfectly all the time - so we didn't know what to expect with an Android), but we are returning.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: No IAP *whatsoever* for kids' FreeTime profiles
review_body:
Buyer beware: if you set up a FreeTime profile for your child, there is absolutely no way for you to make in-app purchases for any apps he or she runs, nor can you do it on your own account and have it transfer to the child's account. Every single competitor gives the option of a parent putting in a password, or setting a purchase limit for their child -- but not Amazon.

Best of all, when people on the Amazon forums complained about this, all their staff have given is repeated generic "we've passed your input on to the relevant team" responses (for months on end) -- except for one flippant response of "this is how it's made".

But hey, why should you care, right Amazon? You already have our money, after all...

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body:
I have mixed feelings, but as I was writing my review I've found I was more disappointed than I originally thought. I've had the regular kindle and I didn't like it. I've had the paperwhite which I felt was an improvement, but it still wasn't everything I was looking for. For Christmas I received the kindle fire hd. I think if I was living in the US. I would be happier with it. As it is the internet runs slow because everything goes through Amazon and I've had to download Google Chrome for a decent internet connection. My prime membership doesn't work well either because even though Amazon has a set up feature for VPN use Amazon won't connect to the prime features when I use the VPN. The ads on the free apps are more demanding than any ads on my iPad- at least on the iPad I didn't have to press x to close the banner especially not after every level of each game played. I can also buy music with the cursed one click, (but once again no prime features). The parental controls is a bit frustrating it is too easy to lock things and nearly impossible to figure out how to unlock, so I'm just using the device for me and unblocked everything everything except the login, but I would still prefer to have 1 click off.
Ultimately I was hoping for an alternative device to read my kindle books and view my prime membership features as I have to complete with others for time on my iPad. At the moment I can't use my Amazon Prime features so this Kindle doesn't currently meet my needs which had left me disappointed and I really wanted to like this device more, but it's not allowing me to use my prime features as I was expecting it to. I'm starting to look at other devices hoping that maybe I can use another tablet the same way I was hoping to use the Kindle.
On a positive note the books are in color, audiobooks play well, the camera is decent, and there is music, apps, Internet, as well. I can see the pictures in my Kindle cookbooks but I'm also disappointed that there aren't more photos, but that has more to do with the cookbook than the Kindle.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: and like some and not others
review_body:
I had the first generation Kindle Fire, but the charging unit died a few months ago so I decided to get the 2014 Fire HD 7" 8GB. I've only had it a few days so I'm still getting familiar with the new features, and like some and not others.
Like the front & rear-facing camera, but pictures and videos are best when taken in bright light. Otherwise, the picture is grainy.
Love the improved speakers; the volume gets very loud and the volume/on/off buttons have been relocated.
Like the ability to link Facebook pictures.
Not happy with the color, Cobalt. It looks black.
Not happy the back of the device is not textured (slips out of my hand) and is slightly bigger while display screen is same size. The Kindle Fire (1st gen) fit perfectly in my hand and had a spongy back which prevented slips.
Don't like I can't move the favorites icons; the most recent is at the bottom. If someone knows, please let me know.
Some of the apps don't work, but I realize that is an app developer issue.
All-in-all, I'm happy to have another Kindle/Fire.

review_body: This is the second kindle I have owned. My first kindle I had for about a year but then all of a sudden it wouldn't stay off. I'd turn it off and it would turn back on. I called Amazon and they gave me this one as a replacement. It worked well until about a year mark (again the same amount of time as the original one) and then it just would not turn on! It seems like poor manufacturing. I want a product that actually works. It just seems to big of a coincidence that both kindles has electronic malfunctioning and that they stopped working right when the warranty ended. Not happy with this product at all!

After searching, you can only hook up directly to your TV with a specialized HDMI cord, which is not included.  Would be nice if they could integrate the two amazon products to work with eachother.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: We purchased the Kindle Fire HD7 this Christmas for our kids and we are very disappointed. This tablet is very complicated to maneuver through, the battery life so far lasts about 2 hours with steady use. Its supposed to have 8GB of storage, but when looking in the hard drive settings it only displays 5GB. Ummm, what? The programs and applications that come pre-loaded and are necessary to run the tablet take up at least 2GB. Diving deeper into the Fire it is very tough to basically work through it to find what you're looking for, whether it be a downloaded app or the settings related to each profile in relation to the general settings of the tablet itself. Basically, we feel like a couple of monkeys with sticks trying to operate a clunky D8 bulldozer. We're returning this ASAP. ----- Amazon--> fire and/or get your money back from the company that designed the operating platform for this hunk of crap you're selling to people.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: Being the Fire camara doesnt have a LED flash, what else could they do aside for giving you a white screen?

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: This will not connect with our home Wi-Fi. And tha't just bunk, b/c every other wireless device we own will connect without any problem.  Amazon's "help" for that problem is no help at all.  "Make sure your wireless is on.  DUH!"  And once I started searching for help for this on the internet, I found TONS of people who have the same problem. But, there is no solution. Apparently it either works with your home wifi or it doesn't.  And if it doesn't, there is nothing you can do about it.  Wake up Amazon!!! If everybody else can make Wi-Fi stuff that syncs without any problem, you can too.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: The Fire could be friendlier to the user....
review_body: The Fire could be friendlier to the user, by a lot.  The specs are good, the stereo sound is great (would be better if located in the front), the \\"plastic\\" feel casing and oversized bezel around the screen doesn't bother me much, in fact I like to hold my thumb there; however, the inability to customize the look of the user interface bugs me.  I hate the whole carousel thing....it's rather too large for me -- I feel stupid looking at/scrolling thru oversized icons. The carousel is not customizable either: things you don't want to show up, will again show up even after removing it, once you use the app again.    ADD 12/27/14:  I enjoy having the menu buttons on the right hand side in landscape mode.  (Too bad no customization for left handed people.) Definitely better than having it at the bottom, like my wife's Galaxy Tab.    Not being able to easily use google products such as YouTube app or Chrome browser is annoying. (I can't say I blame them...they're competitors!) At least going to YouTube.com works fine.    You cannot use widgets.  =(  I'll miss my weather widget.    I haven't found an easy way to ensure programs are not running in the background...I feel that something is going on because the battery dropped 10% while I was sleeping with the screen turned off.  Maybe there's an app for that.  Overall, I think the battery life could be better.    I'm going to keep it of course, it was a gift and I'm not shy with figuring out how to side load things or root the operating system all together to get what I want....it would be nice to not have to do the workarounds.    In the end however, I would not recommend this device, nor buy another Amazon device product, to include the Fire Phone, because of the lack of personal customization.  BUT, I'm sure some people don't mind, good for them, but not me.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: I like the content options, size, color options and weight, but something about the screen is making me very dizzy. I don't know if it's the scrolling, which I can't seem to adjust, or the polarized screen. Is there another model that does not cause dizziness? I've seen a few other comments about this. I'd rather not add a screen protector, but if it really helps, maybe that's OK. I was really hoping for the less-glare-y screen (basically more matte) that the Fires used to have. I would even go with a 6-inch model if it did not cause dizziness. Any suggestions?  Update; Jan. 2, 2015: I decided to return this device. I ordered a Voyage. Although the Voyage is pretty much a uni-tasker, I hope it works well and does not cause dizziness.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: ipad would of been a better choice
review_body: It okay wasent reallyn impressed ,ipad would of been a better choice

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body:
I definitely made a very expensive mistake.
There is absolutely nothing new on this Kindle Fire 7 that wasn't on my original Kindle Fire (after less than 2 years the internal connector for charger didn't accept the charger cord anymore and Amazon wasn't interested in repairing it).
This Fire is definitely targeted to just a certain user audience - most people won't even use all the battery consuming bells and whistles.
The battery has such a short life that it is impossible to use it for a day without plugging in to recharge.. AND - charging extra for the electric plug connector is a SCAM.
This thing is NOT worth the $$..The instructions and advice videos on the Amazon web site are GROSS - they are absolutely no help at all.
Any helpful advice comes from plowing through the messages from users.
The covers all open backwards - not like a normal book.
The cord connection is VERY touchy and sometimes works and sometimes needs to be played with.
My old (but still running - but getting tired) Kindle keyboard machine works better than this, lasts longer, connects to the web, and has a convertible connection cord..
PLEASE bring back a simple Kindle for reading, audio, and web connection for those of us who have enough other electronics with all the bells and whistles we need.
Don't buy it unless you want a new plaything..

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Don't expect a full featured android tablet - Great e-reader!
review_body: The Fire HD7 works very well as a e-reader and can play games found on the Amazon Marketplace fairly well (mine locks up occasionally with the games I've tried). However, don't plan to use it for ChromeCast or expect much luck side loading Firefox or any number of other typical android applications found on other marketplaces such as Google Play or 1st Marketplace, you'll find this device is effectively locked into Amazon even more so than previous tablets offered by Amazon. The variation of Android used for this device seems to have branched far enough from Android that many apps from other markets simply don't start. If you just plan to use it as an e-reader with the feature to borrow books on Prime, don't mind the screen saver advertisements, and don't mind limiting to the games found on the amazon store, this tablet will work very well. Just don't expect to a full featured Android tablet, you will be disappointed.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: ... books to load on my new fire -- this sucks -- amazon doesn't even see it as a registered ...
review_body: I can't get my Kindle books to load on my new fire -- this sucks -- amazon doesn't even see it as a registered device.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Don't buy for small kids, but 4-5yrs and up is probably good.
review_body:
Several review sites say that this is good for kids, but the lack of a "home" button (like on an iPad) makes it difficult for small children to figure out how to return to the main menu. However, the built in Freeplay option is a great addition that iPad does not have, at least out of the box. Freeplay (I think that is the right name for it) gives kids a simple menu and prevents them from buying apps.

Note: my son is not quite two years old, but uses an iPad really well. I got the Fire because it was a cheap alternative, but the lack of the home button makes it somewhat unusable. He will probably be able to use it later on.

I received my replacement expecting a brand new Kindle.  Instead, I was sent a refurbished one.  I am very disappointed.  If I had purchased my Kindle through a retail store, I would have received a brand new one, not refurbished, as a replacement.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Not all Fire Apps work with this
review_body: I currently own a Fire 7" HDX that I love, and purchased a Fire HD 7" with 16GB for my daughter to replace her Nook.  One of the main reasons we were replacing the Nook was so she could download and use the Disney Channel and Disney Channel Jr. Apps. which are available on my HDX.  These are not available on her HD, and she is very disappointed.  There is nothing on the App description that indicates that there is a limitation, but the product description does state that it works with the Kindle Fire.  If the HD will not work with all apps, this should be stated and if the app will be available in the future (even if the time-line is TBD) the product description should be updated to reflect this.

Impossible to use easily with my finger size and after 20 minutes of trying to enter my WiFi password without success, gave up. The button keyboard of my old Kindle is much easier to use. I strictly use my Kindle for reading, so do not need or want all of the extra capabilities. This was a gift and not something I would have bought for myself. product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: Worst purchase I have every made, I should have trusted my instincts to go with an iPad Mini, but I decided that I go for the cheaper alternative instead.  Well while setting up this device with Freetime unlimited I manage to get myself locked out by parental controls, I contact customer service and they tell me to deregister the device so that I can register the device again.  The device deregisters from my amazon.com account and my device, except now that I go to register on the device I get a \\"registration error\\" and cannot register it again.  I spend 3 hours with Kindle technical support and they have no idea why the device is now in a limbo state and they say that it is not connected to Wifi and that I should test it with the Silk Browser... except that the Silk browser is blocked by parental controls that I cannot unlock.  I switch 3 wifi hotspots to prove the point that it is not a connection issue especially since I have 2 kindles and 2 other HD 7's that I am setting up which are operating fine.  As the parental code is device specific (I must have mis-typed this device over the others) there is nothing they can do except factory reset, except they can't even do that because they can't ping, they can't remote alarm, they can't even send out a remote factory reset because the device exists as if it is not even connected to wifi (which I assure you it is).  Essentially I've first handedly at the instruction of Amazon quarantined my device into a state of limbo.  To make matters worse?  This is 9:30 pm to 12:48 am Christmas morning and 1 of 3 of my kiddos is going to be heartbroken tomorrow as to why his kindle is deregistered and has nothing on it except a parental control prompt that we can't get rid of.. Amazon's solution?  Yeah, there's no \\"let's send Doug a new one next dat air and we'll sort out this software issue on our end\\" it's \\"you can always choose to return it, but until our development team explicitly states that it is beyond troubleshooting you will need to be patient and work with them...\\" over the next 2-5 business days, which is what, 2 weeks!??  Mind you this is brand new out of the box while setting them up as Christmas gifts.  Absolute epic fail.  If it weren't for purchase as disposable tablets for the kids I wouldn't even bother anymore.  If you have the means steer clear of Amazon hardware and invest in a Apple iPad Mini instead.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: I couldn't install Google Apps, and not really fast.
review_body:
I bought this for my wife. However, she had the hardest time using it. I think mainly because the interface is so different. If this is your first tablet, you will not have that hard of a time using it. But the real problem for me was the Amazon App Store. Because this is custom build of Android, there are several applications you can not download. Usually google apps. Even if you side load it, it doesnt work. It is missing Google services that run in the background of most tablets.

So with that being a big disappointment, there was another thing. Although the system ran really quick, apps sometimes didn't. I feel like it had 2 processors.(I don't know if it does or not) one for system and one for apps. Although it was super quick navigating once you figured out where everything was. Applications would take awhile to load. It could be that these applications were pretty big. But those 2 things were the deal breaker for us.

I couldn't install Play Books by Google or really anything by Google, even side loading it.

review_body: Got this as a gift less than two weeks ago. Now it won't even turn on. Save your money and get a real tablet. That way you can get real OS and apps.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: okay but not great: Update: Good Christmas gift
review_body: There's a few things wrong with this kindle. The most disappointing thing is it freezes, a lot. I bought the tablet for my lil sister and shes not complaining,  she likes it a lot but I'm complaining because i bought it for $109(it was on sale) payed $30( on sale) 2 years warranty plus a case for $20. This to me is a lot of money to have a tablet that keeps frezzing. One more important and disappointing thing, the memory.  She downloaded about 10 games and the memory was full, and we don't no how to uninstall some games. Over all im glad i bought it even though it does frezzes a lot n does not have enough space, the reason is because i wanted something educational for my lil sister and now she has one. Update: 10/11/2016 I'm a prime member and I have to say I LOVE PRIME!! I called their customer service and when there was nothing they could do about it THEY SHIPPED ME A NEW ONE!!! oh yea, I have to say I have two years warrant on it. But anyways my little sister has had their tablet replaced THREE things now.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: If i get one more message telling me "not compatible ...
review_body: If i get one more message telling me "not compatible with device" I am going to scream. Can't even download FREE aps without a credit card on file. Amazon account info is not secure and it does not prompt for password, so basically anyone can purchase anything as long as the have access to the device. Does not stream internet music, once an APP is downloaded it does not play music. Seriously thinking about sending it back to get an iPad. No wonder Apple leads in this market.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: I still like it, but it's really irritating when the Amazon app/pages stop loading. I've had to restart my device already and I've only had it for a week. Considering that this is a [brand new] Amazon device, shouldn't that be the only app that doesn't crash? Also, this device takes horrible, grainy, unclear pictures. But I guess that's okay since I didn't really buy this for taking pictures; it would have been cool though since, I mean, there's two cameras on this thing. I'm really hoping I don't find anything else to dislike about this because I don't want to feel like I've wasted my money. Maybe I should have just bought one of the others that's strictly for reading... :/

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: came with no instrutions to use

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: Can not access the Google play store!  You can only install apps from Amazon's store which does not have nearly the selection of the play store or any Google apps that I have found.  Amazon has even prevented Google play services from running so if you try to install Google apps (GMail, Google+, etc) manually, most will not run.  It never occurred to me that an Android (Google OS) based device would not run Google apps and seems misleading when the advertisement says it runs Android apps.  If I buy a Windows based computer I would expect to be able to run MS Office.      The screen resolution is pretty good.  I bought this mostly so I would be able to watch video on a screen bigger than my (real Android) phone.  For that reason it serves its purpose.  The interface is Amazon's interface.  It takes some getting used to but once you figure it out its not to bad.      Basically its a device for playing media purchased through Amazon.  Now I know why it's cheaper than a 'real' android tablet.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Nothing wrong with Kindle, it is Amazon that is broken!
review_body: This is probably an OK tablet; however, I am returning it because Amazon (or their 3rd party vendor) cheated me out of $43 on an iPad trade-in.  Yeah, I know, it is not rally about the tablet . . . . it is how Amazon has treated me and their inability to listen to my complaint.  I might have been able to move on, but they STILL have not replied to my inquiry about the trade-in.  It has been sitting out there since December 12th.  Not only that, they no longer even read your inquiries.  They just ship them off to any department that seems to fit.  I have always loved Amazon.  Yes, I will still buy stuff from them if it benefits me (cost and delivery), but I am "done" being a fan of theirs.  Whenever a big company promotes its desire to be the most customer centric company in world you can figure there are issues.  Amazon, all you had to do was listen . . . . . . very disappointed in you.  You have become just another vendor to me.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: especially if you are boasting it to be the perfect family solution
review_body:
Not truly a family solution as they advertise it.
It's time for them to step up and get this right, especially if you are boasting it to be the perfect family solution. It is certainly not. Your internet choices are still all or nothing outside of the "Revolutionary parental controls with Amazon FreeTime". If you choose to set things up in FreeTime, you can only allow access to sites they have predetermined. So, if my child needs to visit a website for school that is not on Amazon's list she can't do it in FreeTime. The only way she could access it would be for me to give her full free range of the internet. The current settings are great for the very young and for adults, but still fail the pre-teen and teen crowd. I think the way they are marketing this product as "great for the whole family" is dishonest. They need to spell it out so there is no confusion on the consumer's end. I hope that parents read this so they at least know about this limitation prior to purchasing because this is so important to all of us.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Would not recommend for a tablet but good for kids books and ...
review_body: Slow for Internet even with high speed service.  Would not recommend for a tablet but good for kids books and some of the game if the app does not freeze up

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: This is not a tablet for the older generation or those who struggle with technology.
review_body:
User interface is confusing. to do anything you need to input your credit card information. to buy any kindle books it requires your credit card information. I bought a amazon gift card and the kindle for my grandma because she has a difficult time reading the small font of normal books. I couldn't simply purchase a book with the gift card on the kindle. It stupidly kept saying give us your credit card information for one touch buying. That is so dumb. This should not be the default feature first. Second you should be able to easily change it. I am so freaking disappointed with this product.

Further, anyone reading this is probably going to do more research into the product than I did which of course is smart, but what I didn't know, is that the fire tablets don't use the wisper net technology to download books to the tablets, but rather a wifi connection is required.

This is not a tablet for the older generation or those who struggle with technology.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Not thrilled - but there are pluses and minuses
review_body:
I hadn't been aware that it is not possible to download books from foreign countries, (specifically France) even through Amazon.fr. That was one of the main reasons I bought the Kindle; otherwise I might have opted for a different notebook. This is, in fact, my first notebook, so I can't compare to anything else.

I do like it in other ways. The screen is very readable. It's not particularly comfortable to hold, though.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Will never buy again at this rate
review_body: I don't care what a great deal the hardware is for the price because it's a severely crippled Android tablet that might as well not be Android thanks to lack of Play Store and Play services. To make matters worse, they force their updates with no prompts and ability to decline so now they're sneaking FireOS onto devices that were otherwise previously useful. If they provided the ability to install Google Play Services and PLay Store (those things that made Android so useful to begin with), I could deal with this, but unrootable AND without Google Services makes it useless to me and hardly useful as an Android device yet they happily use the Android code-base.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB

If it dies again, then I'm done with Kindle Fire. My Kindle ereader is more than 3 years old with no problems but I'm extremely disappointed with this 7" Fire HD.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: The tablet is fine.  However, Amazon offered free Prime for 30 days and cut me off after 4 days.  They requested a credit card number NOW.  I think they could fulfill that offer and then request the credit card.  Very disappointed.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: This item broke within the first week. It was ...
review_body: This item broke within the first week.  It was working one night while I was reading in bed, and by next morning, the device would no longer power on.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: UPDATE: After six months of buying and using this kindle, it went dead. No power, no nothing. The battery was fully charge when it shut down but nothing is happening.  I am so disappointed. I was really loving my kindle. The sound and picture quality were superb. I was able to peruse every aspect of the internet including my emails. I even gave it five stars initially. NOW, I give it one star and even that is a stretch. I'm aware that each individual experience with their kindle is different, so i wont say don't buy it but just be mindful of the possibility that my experience could be your experience. So buyers beware.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: Was disappointed with not being able to get all my games for free on this device .

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_body: Its a very cheap tablet thats what made it appealing over the bigger name competitors. It's good if you just want to check social media and go on the Internet. It can't open email attachments, and this was made in 2014? If you click a link you better have a few minutes and even then you may have to start over and re click and hope the seperate window loads this time. My last and biggest complaint about the device is that the price is so low because it is used as an advertisement. Everytime you log in you have to look at the "deal of the day" in the background. It does not slow you down but it bothers me that I am being bombarded with advertisements on my private device and to turn that feature off you have to pay amazon! Buy a different device.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: I do like my kindle fire but not as much as my ...
review_body: I bought this to replace my Google Nexus 7 that I have had for two years. My Nexus still worked but the charging port was going out and it was a pain to try and keep charged. I do like my kindle fire but not as much as my Nexus. Maybe it's just because I have had android device's for so long.  I don't like that you can't tag people in facebook. I haven't yet figured out how to get Instagram. It seems like I have to press on the links REALLY HARD or it just sits and does nothing or it will go to the link but not ever load. product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Parental Controls Leave a Little to Be Desired
review_body:
The tablet itself runs well. The cusotmer service is outstanding. Already had an issue with battery draining completely in less than eight hours overnight. Seems that has been corrected -- possibly an app caused it. Removed some apps we did not want and was able to leave wireless on without the battery draining.

My issue is with the parental controls. It seems that Amazon Free Time is the app for creating profiles. Setting up child auomatically restricts accces to texting, emails and the store. I want purchases disabled however, I believe I should have the decision whether are not to allow texts and emails for my child. I found a texting app that would allow a child to text and will be looking for email. Why can't I just pick and choose what I want my child to have access??? Don't understand why there are parental control features that cannot be used with the child profile. The parental controls are not great.

App selection for android and i-tunes is better that for the Fire HD. The apps are real easy to put on and off of the tablet if it is not what was wanted. The apps can be searched by device -- for example Minion Rush is not available on tablet but on Fire TV. Kind of interesting some of the apps not available on Fire HD 7.

Overall, not a bad choice for the price. If you are looking for apps, games and amazon prime, this is a perfect choice. Probably would not pick this just to have a tablet.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Amazon Kindle Fire Customer Service Marathon and  a few laughs
review_body: Customer service is terrible!!! Ordered and received a NEW Kindle Fire back in November. Opened the box a week before Christmas to make sure it was charged etc. and it was dead. So I went through all the tech support instructions checking other plugs and holding down the power button etc. They said they would send a replacement and have it to me in two days.    Well, I got it and it was a refurbished Kindle with no power adapter. SO, I paid for a brand new kindle which was defective now I end up with a refurbished kindle and no power adapter for the price of a new one. NOT A GREAT DEAL!!! MERRY CHRISTAMS from AMAZON!    Wow, I thought with an Amazon branded product the customer service would be  a lot better! VERY disappointed in Amazon!!    (UPDATE) A day after I was told by a very laid back lady from customer service with a fun Jamaican accent, I'd have to just live with the refurbished Kindle, \\"what ya gonna do?\\". I still laugh when I think of that lady. I got a call back from Amazon customer service, and after another hour on the phone was told a new one was on the way to replace the defective new one! Finally, what should have been an easy 10 minute conversation with customer service to fix took many days and many, many hours on the phone and chat with customer service with many different people to finally get fixed. Persistence pays off I guess.     They earned some stars back from 1 to 3, or wait a minute did I earn the stars?

review_headline: You better not curse you better not cry if your Kindle conks out on the first night
review_body:
My last kindle lasted about 3 years until last week when it unexpectedly stopped charging. I used the special sale to buy a new one. I have not still confronted the issues which caused the old one to conk out. I figured 3 years is a health life for a tablet. The new one lasted about a week before it conked out. I only see the Amazon logo on the screen after charging. I guess the hurry to get product out for the holiday rush kind of forced them to cut corners. I requested a replacement. I hope this is a one off thing and the replacement lasts a tad bit longer.

The kindle that conked out already has my personal information and I am unable to delete it before sending it back to Amazon which has me a bit worried. My email to Amazon requesting information on the warranty and requesting info on extended warranty got me a 'standardized response'. Customer service - another victim of the holiday rush.

That said it is a good tablet for the price.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Buy a Samsung instead, the custom Amazon interface has severely limited the best aspects of having an Android tablet
review_body:
I'm a huge android fan and was trying to decide between this and the Samsung tab for my daughter. I have a Samsung Note and everyone in our home has Samsung Galaxy S4 phones. I've also had other Android tablets in the past. I picked this because it had a bit faster processor speed than the Tab and the tech reviews online were glowing. However, I've found it to be an awful watered-down version of an Android tablet, with many Android apps and features just not available because of the dumbed down interface that forces use of Amazon app store and prohibits access to the main and largest Android app store, Google Play. It also lacks other great android features commonly found on the Samsung and Nexus Android tablets.

What this means:

If you have bought apps in the Google play store in the past (for previous tablets, phone, etc.) you WILL NOT be able to access them, download them, or use them at all on this tablet unless you root it, which then invalidates all warranties, etc. (and you also need decent tech abilities were you to want to try to root it). The interface does not allow you to download the Google Play store, nor can you try to get apps from it via the browser, as something about the way they've programmed the Fire essentially makes it invisible to the Android Play store, so that the store doesn't recognize the Fire tablet as being an Android.

Even if you've never bought anything from the Google Play store, it's still a bummer for you because the Amazon app store has a VERY limited selection of apps. If you're getting this for your kid, they want to change the wall papers and personalize the tablet. There is a very limited selection of not very interesting wallpapers and it's just not optimized to enhance your experience by customizing it with apps you'd like because the selection is so very limited. I have about 30 some apps in my Google play account. Once owned, you can use them for any of your Android products (usually) and once you login to your google account you have easy access to download them all to your new device. Can't do that with the Fire at all. So even if it does have some of the apps I like and use, I'd have to pay for them again, via the Amazon app store in order to have them. I have a bunch of medical apps that I use and some of them are available in the Amazon store, but most are not. Same with the apps my daughter has and even more so with the wallpapers and other personalizations that are typically available for Android products.

My daughter, when checking out this tablet and attempting to customize it, was seriously disappointed and upset with it, stating "my Android phone has more capabilities and things to do with it than this tablet!". If your kid is at all tech savvy they will hate this tablet.

Unfortunately it seems like Amazon has taken a great little tablet but stripped it of it's great abilities in order to force-funnel all owners into buying from their limited app store, streaming only their videos and music, disallowing access to other great media and news and useful applications that are found in the Google Play store, thus limiting it's capabilities. There may be other sites that it limits the use of as I didn't do an exhaustive search, prohibiting Google Play access was enough for me to know we'd never be happy with it. I'd say the apps it comes with, already loaded are disappointing as well when compared to what comes on a real android tablet (one that lets you access the full world of apps, music, books & magazines, blogs & posts, etc. that most every other Android tablet can access) It's kind of like buying a truck but blocking off the back bed area (the box area where you can put tons of stuff, the essential part of a truck that makes it so useful..) so that you can never put anything in it or use it, you can only put stuff in the front cab - why bother with a truck then?

If you want a true Android with allthe capabilities of an android (and I can think of no reason that you wouldn't want that...) then you really need to buy an alternate Android tablet. I'd suggest looking at the Samsung tablets, such as the tab or note. I am not an Apple fan at all, but I would even say to get an iPad over this tablet as it's capabilities have just been too stunted by the limits imposed by Amazon's interface. It's very disappointing as in general I'm a huge Amazon fan and I love my Amazon Fire TV and basic kindle. However, with this they've very much disappointed me. This tablet is limited to streaming video & music from Amazon, downloading Amazon books and light/limited internet browsing. It's true capabilities have been cut off.

SUMMARY: Severely limited use as you can't access the thousands of apps and goodies on Google Play as the Amazon interface prohibits downloading the Google Play app and has made the tablet unrecognizable as an Android if you access Google Play via the browser. You'd have to root it in order to change this which will invalidate your warranty. This denied access to Google Play severely limits the capabilities of your tablet. If you want a real Android tablet with full functionality look at the Samsung Tab or Samsung Note instead. The decision by Amazon to prohibit full access to the plethora of Android features and apps is very disappointing.the capabilities of an android (and I can think of no reason that you wouldn't want that...) then you really need to buy an alternate Android tablet. I'd suggest looking at the Samsung tablets, such as the tab or note. I am not an Apple fan at all, but I would even say to get an iPad over this tablet as it's capabilities have just been too stunted by the limits imposed by Amazon's interface. It's very disappointing as in general I'm a huge Amazon fan and I love my Amazon Fire TV and basic kindle. However, with this they've very much disappointed me. This tablet is limited to streaming video & music from Amazon, downloading Amazon books and light/limited internet browsing. It's true capabilities have been cut off.

SUMMARY: Severely limited use as you can't access the thousands of apps and goodies on Google Play as the Amazon interface prohibits downloading the Google Play app and has made the tablet unrecognizable as an Android if you access Google Play via the browser. You'd have to root it in order to change this which will invalidate your warranty. This denied access to Google Play severely limits the capabilities of your tablet. If you want a real Android tablet with full functionality look at the Samsung Tab or Samsung Note instead. The decision by Amazon to prohibit full access to the plethora of Android features and apps is very disappointing.

product_title: Fire HD 7, 7" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB
review_headline: Not even close to competing with a stock Android tablet
review_body:
I am a huge fan of Amazon, but they have ruined Android with all their restrictions, customizations and lack of Google Play. I knew the device wouldn't have Google Play, but I was shocked to see that NOTHING Google was actually a Google app. All Google apps (Gmail, YouTube, etc) are third party apps that, quite frankly, suck. I should have checked into that more, but trusting Amazon to have a good product I failed to check further (my fault). However, the fact still remains that this is nothing like an Android tablet and basically is a Kindle that can browse the internet (only on the Silk browser) and play games. It's not an Android tablet, it's a jazzed up Kindle with a terrible UI. Amazon promotes this thing as an alternative to higher priced Android tablets. It comes nowhere close to competing with a tablet offering Android with the Google Play Store. Even Apple, the most restrictive company out there, allows Google Apps on their devices. Amazon needs to get with the program and offer a more user friendly OS that doesn't exclude people from using Google Play. I have no doubt that Google Play would be on the Kindle Fire if Amazon wanted it.

All that said, I can make the Kindle Fire work for me. I can root the device (yes, void the warranty) and add Google Play or sideload the Google apps I want. It's not the end of the world, but it shouldn't have to be that way. I haven't decided yet if I'll be keeping it or returning it and going with a Galaxy Tab 4.
